section_body:
Main article: [Symptoms of COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symptoms_of_COVID-19 "Symptoms of COVID-19")

[![Image 28](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg/500px-Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Symptoms_of_coronavirus_disease_2019_4.0.svg)

[Symptoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signs_and_symptoms "Signs and symptoms") of COVID-19

Symptoms of COVID-19 are variable, ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness.[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Sym-104)[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Grant_et_al_2020-105) Common symptoms include headache, [loss of smell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anosmia "Anosmia") and [taste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ageusia "Ageusia"), [nasal congestion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasal_obstruction "Nasal obstruction") and [runny nose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhinorrhea "Rhinorrhea"), cough, [muscle pain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_pain "Muscle pain"), [sore throat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sore_throat "Sore throat"), fever, [diarrhoea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diarrhea "Diarrhea"), and [breathing difficulties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breathing_difficulties "Breathing difficulties").[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Sym-104) People with the same infection may have different symptoms, and their symptoms may change over time. Three common clusters of symptoms have been identified: one respiratory symptom cluster with cough, [sputum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sputum "Sputum"), shortness of breath, and fever; a musculoskeletal symptom cluster with muscle and joint pain, headache, and fatigue; a cluster of digestive symptoms with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhoea.[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ECDC-106) In people without prior ear, nose, and throat disorders, [loss of taste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypogeusia "Hypogeusia") combined with [loss of smell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyposmia "Hyposmia") is associated with [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19") and is reported in as many as 88% of cases.[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Krishnan-107)[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-108)[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid32483687-109)

triples.sentence: Symptoms of COVID-19 are variable, ranging from mild symptoms to severe illness.[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Sym-104)[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Grant_et_al_2020-105)
triples.statement: The symptoms of COVID-19 vary, with a range from mild to severe illness.

triples.sentence: Common symptoms include headache, [loss of smell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anosmia "Anosmia") and [taste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ageusia "Ageusia"), [nasal congestion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasal_obstruction "Nasal obstruction") and [runny nose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhinorrhea "Rhinorrhea"), cough, [muscle pain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_pain "Muscle pain"), [sore throat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sore_throat "Sore throat"), fever, [diarrhoea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diarrhea "Diarrhea"), and [breathing difficulties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breathing_difficulties "Breathing difficulties").[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Sym-104)
triples.statement: Common symptoms of COVID-19 include headache, loss of smell and taste, nasal congestion, runny nose, cough, muscle pain, sore throat, fever, diarrhoea, and breathing difficulties.

triples.sentence: Three common clusters of symptoms have been identified: one respiratory symptom cluster with cough, [sputum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sputum "Sputum"), shortness of breath, and fever; a musculoskeletal symptom cluster with muscle and joint pain, headache, and fatigue; a cluster of digestive symptoms with abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhoea.[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ECDC-106)
triples.statement: Three common symptom clusters have been identified: a respiratory cluster (cough, sputum, shortness of breath, fever), a musculoskeletal cluster (muscle/joint pain, headache, fatigue), and a digestive cluster (abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea).

section_body:
Main article: [Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2 "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2")

[![Image 29](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg/250px-Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Coronavirus_virion_structure.svg)

Illustration of SARS-CoV-2 [virion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virion "Virion")

SARS‑CoV‑2 belongs to the broad family of viruses known as [coronaviruses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus "Coronavirus").[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fox2020-115) It is a [positive-sense single-stranded RNA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positive-sense_single-stranded_RNA_virus "Positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus") (+ssRNA) virus, with a single linear RNA segment. Coronaviruses infect humans, other mammals, including livestock and companion animals, and avian species.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-V'kovskik:21-116)

Human coronaviruses are capable of causing illnesses ranging from the [common cold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_cold "Common cold") to more severe diseases such as [Middle East respiratory syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome "Middle East respiratory syndrome") (MERS, fatality rate ≈34%). SARS-CoV-2 is the seventh known coronavirus to infect people, after [229E](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_coronavirus_229E "Human coronavirus 229E"), [NL63](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_coronavirus_NL63 "Human coronavirus NL63"), [OC43](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_coronavirus_OC43 "Human coronavirus OC43"), [HKU1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_coronavirus_HKU1 "Human coronavirus HKU1"), [MERS-CoV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome-related_coronavirus "Middle East respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus"), and the original [SARS-CoV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus").[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NEJM-Novel-117)

triples.sentence: SARS‑CoV‑2 belongs to the broad family of viruses known as [coronaviruses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus "Coronavirus").[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Fox2020-115)
triples.statement: SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the coronavirus family of viruses.

triples.sentence: Coronaviruses infect humans, other mammals, including livestock and companion animals, and avian species.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-V'kovskik:21-116)
triples.statement: Coronaviruses infect humans, other mammals (including livestock and companion animals), and avian species.

triples.sentence: SARS-CoV-2 is the seventh known coronavirus to infect people, after [229E](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_coronavirus_229E "Human coronavirus 229E"), [NL63](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_coronavirus_NL63 "Human coronavirus NL63"), [OC43](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_coronavirus_OC43 "Human coronavirus OC43"), [HKU1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_coronavirus_HKU1 "Human coronavirus HKU1"), [MERS-CoV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome-related_coronavirus "Middle East respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus"), and the original [SARS-CoV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus").[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NEJM-Novel-117)
triples.statement: SARS-CoV-2 is the seventh known coronavirus to infect people, following 229E, NL63, OC43, HKU1, MERS-CoV, and the original SARS-CoV.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 §Diagnosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19#Diagnosis "COVID-19")

[![Image 30](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/2020Sept26-BioFire-Waldron-HR.jpg/250px-2020Sept26-BioFire-Waldron-HR.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2020Sept26-BioFire-Waldron-HR.jpg)

A nurse at [McMurdo Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McMurdo_Station "McMurdo Station") sets up the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing equipment, in September 2020

The standard method of testing for presence of SARS-CoV-2 is a [nucleic acid test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleic_acid_test "Nucleic acid test"),[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200130cdc-118) which detects the presence of viral RNA fragments.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_InterimGuidance-119) As these tests detect RNA but not infectious virus, its "ability to determine duration of infectivity of patients is limited".[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-2k0iS-120) The test is typically done on respiratory samples obtained by a [nasopharyngeal swab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasopharyngeal_swab "Nasopharyngeal swab"); however, a nasal swab or sputum sample may also be used.[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CDC2020Testing-121)[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200129cdc-122) The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-123)

triples.sentence: The standard method of testing for presence of SARS-CoV-2 is a [nucleic acid test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleic_acid_test "Nucleic acid test"),[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200130cdc-118) which detects the presence of viral RNA fragments.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_InterimGuidance-119)
triples.statement: The standard method for testing for SARS-CoV-2 is a nucleic acid test, which detects viral RNA fragments.

triples.sentence: As these tests detect RNA but not infectious virus, its "ability to determine duration of infectivity of patients is limited".[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-2k0iS-120)
triples.statement: Because these tests detect RNA and not the infectious virus, their ability to determine how long a patient is infectious is limited.

triples.sentence: The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-123)
triples.statement: The WHO has published several testing protocols for the disease.

section_body:
Further information: [COVID-19 §Prevention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19#Prevention "COVID-19"), [Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_masks_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Face masks during the COVID-19 pandemic"), and [Social distancing measures related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distancing_measures_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Social distancing measures related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 31](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/How_to_Contain_COVID-19_icon_%28COVID19.GOV.PH%29.svg/250px-How_to_Contain_COVID-19_icon_%28COVID19.GOV.PH%29.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:How_to_Contain_COVID-19_icon_(COVID19.GOV.PH).svg)

Common measures implemented to prevent the spread of the virus

Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include getting vaccinated, staying at home or spending more time outdoors, avoiding crowded places, keeping distance from others, wearing a mask in public, ventilating indoor spaces, managing potential exposure durations, washing hands with soap and water often and for at least twenty seconds, practising good respiratory hygiene, and avoiding touching the eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cdc-prev-124)[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-who2023-125)

Those diagnosed with COVID-19 or who believe they may be infected are advised by healthcare authorities to stay home except to get medical care, call ahead before visiting a healthcare provider, wear a face mask before entering the healthcare provider's office and when in any room or vehicle with another person, cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue, regularly wash hands with soap and water and avoid sharing personal household items.[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-126)[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-127)[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-128)

triples.sentence: Preventive measures to reduce the chances of infection include getting vaccinated, staying at home or spending more time outdoors, avoiding crowded places, keeping distance from others, wearing a mask in public, ventilating indoor spaces, managing potential exposure durations, washing hands with soap and water often and for at least twenty seconds, practising good respiratory hygiene, and avoiding touching the eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cdc-prev-124)[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-who2023-125)
triples.statement: Preventive measures to reduce the chances of COVID-19 infection include vaccination, staying home, avoiding crowds, social distancing, wearing masks, ventilating indoor spaces, managing exposure durations, frequent hand washing, practicing good respiratory hygiene, and avoiding touching one's face with unwashed hands.

triples.sentence: Those diagnosed with COVID-19 or who believe they may be infected are advised by healthcare authorities to stay home except to get medical care, call ahead before visiting a healthcare provider, wear a face mask before entering the healthcare provider's office and when in any room or vehicle with another person, cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue, regularly wash hands with soap and water and avoid sharing personal household items.[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-126)[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-127)[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-128)
triples.statement: Healthcare authorities advise individuals diagnosed with or suspecting they have COVID-19 to stay home except for medical care, call providers in advance, wear a face mask, cover coughs and sneezes, wash hands regularly, and avoid sharing personal household items.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine "COVID-19 vaccine")

See also: [History of COVID-19 vaccine development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_COVID-19_vaccine_development "History of COVID-19 vaccine development") and [Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_of_COVID-19_vaccines "Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines")

[![Image 32](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Elderly_Slovak_woman_receiving_her_third_Covid-19_vaccine_02.jpg/250px-Elderly_Slovak_woman_receiving_her_third_Covid-19_vaccine_02.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Elderly_Slovak_woman_receiving_her_third_Covid-19_vaccine_02.jpg)

An elderly woman receiving a COVID-19 vaccination in [Slovakia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slovakia "Slovakia")

A COVID-19 [vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine "Vaccine") is intended to provide [acquired immunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquired_immunity "Acquired immunity") against [severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome_coronavirus_2 "Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2") (SARS‑CoV‑2), the virus that causes coronavirus disease 2019 ([COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19")). Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, an established body of knowledge existed about the structure and function of [coronaviruses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus "Coronavirus") causing diseases like [severe acute respiratory syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome "Severe acute respiratory syndrome") (SARS) and [Middle East respiratory syndrome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_East_respiratory_syndrome "Middle East respiratory syndrome") (MERS). This knowledge accelerated the development of various [vaccine platforms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_platform "Vaccine platform") during early 2020.[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid33341119-129) The initial focus of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines was on preventing symptomatic and severe illness.[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-130) The COVID-19 vaccines are widely credited for their role in reducing the severity and death caused by COVID-19.[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-131)[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-132)

As of March 2023, more than 5.5 billion people had received one or more doses[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-133) (11.8 billion in total) in over 197 countries. The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine was the most widely used.[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-134) According to a June 2022 study, COVID-19 vaccines prevented an additional 14.4 million to 19.8 million deaths in 185 countries and territories from 8 December 2020 to 8 December 2021.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-135)[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-136)

On 8 November 2022, the first recombinant protein-based COVID-19 vaccine (Novavax's booster [Nuvaxovid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuvaxovid "Nuvaxovid")) was authorised for use in adults in the United Kingdom. It has subsequently received endorsement/authorisation from the WHO, US, European Union, and Australia.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-137)[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-138)

On 12 November 2022, the WHO released its Global Vaccine Market Report. The report indicated that "inequitable distribution is not unique to COVID-19 vaccines"; countries that are not economically strong struggle to obtain vaccines.[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-139)

On 14 November 2022, the first inhalable vaccine was introduced, developed by Chinese biopharmaceutical company [CanSino Biologics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CanSino_Biologics#COVID-19_vaccine_development "CanSino Biologics"), in the city of Shanghai, China.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-140)

triples.sentence: This knowledge accelerated the development of various [vaccine platforms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_platform "Vaccine platform") during early 2020.[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid33341119-129)
triples.statement: This knowledge accelerated the development of various vaccine platforms during early 2020.

triples.sentence: The initial focus of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines was on preventing symptomatic and severe illness.[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-130)
triples.statement: The initial focus of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines was on preventing symptomatic and severe illness.

triples.sentence: The COVID-19 vaccines are widely credited for their role in reducing the severity and death caused by COVID-19.[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-131)[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-132)
triples.statement: COVID-19 vaccines are widely credited for their role in reducing the severity and death caused by COVID-19.

triples.sentence: According to a June 2022 study, COVID-19 vaccines prevented an additional 14.4 million to 19.8 million deaths in 185 countries and territories from 8 December 2020 to 8 December 2021.[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-135)[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-136)
triples.statement: A June 2022 study estimated that COVID-19 vaccines prevented an additional 14.4 million to 19.8 million deaths in 185 countries and territories from December 8, 2020, to December 8, 2021.

triples.sentence: The report indicated that "inequitable distribution is not unique to COVID-19 vaccines"; countries that are not economically strong struggle to obtain vaccines.[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-139)
triples.statement: The WHO report indicated that inequitable distribution is not unique to COVID-19 vaccines and that less economically strong countries struggle to obtain vaccines.

triples.sentence: On 14 November 2022, the first inhalable vaccine was introduced, developed by Chinese biopharmaceutical company [CanSino Biologics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CanSino_Biologics#COVID-19_vaccine_development "CanSino Biologics"), in the city of Shanghai, China.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-140)
triples.statement: On November 14, 2022, the first inhalable vaccine, developed by CanSino Biologics, was introduced in Shanghai, China.

section_body:
Main article: [Treatment and management of COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treatment_and_management_of_COVID-19 "Treatment and management of COVID-19")

[![Image 33](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg/250px-Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_%2850119127303%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Respiradores_da_USP_utilizados_do_Incor_(50119127303).jpg)

A critically ill patient receiving invasive ventilation in the intensive care unit of the [Heart Institute, University of São Paulo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heart_Institute,_University_of_S%C3%A3o_Paulo "Heart Institute, University of São Paulo") in July 2020. Due to a shortage of mechanical ventilators, a [bridge ventilator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resuscitator "Resuscitator") is being used to automatically actuate a [bag valve mask](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bag_valve_mask "Bag valve mask")

For the first two years of the pandemic, no specific and effective treatment or cure was available.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cdcmuseum-142) In 2021, the European Medicines Agency's (EMA) Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) approved the oral antiviral [protease inhibitor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protease_inhibitor_(pharmacology) "Protease inhibitor (pharmacology)"), [Paxlovid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxlovid "Paxlovid") (nirmatrelvir plus the HIV antiviral [ritonavir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ritonavir "Ritonavir")), to treat adult patients.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-143) FDA later gave it an EUA.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-144)

Most cases of COVID-19 are mild. In these, supportive care includes medication such as [paracetamol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracetamol "Paracetamol") or [NSAIDs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NSAID "NSAID") to relieve symptoms (fever,[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-145) body aches, cough), adequate intake of oral fluids and rest.[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cdcmuseum-142)[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-146) Good personal hygiene and a [healthy diet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthy_diet "Healthy diet") are also recommended.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-147)

[Supportive care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supportive_care "Supportive care") in severe cases includes treatment to [relieve symptoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symptomatic_treatment "Symptomatic treatment"), [fluid therapy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid_replacement "Fluid replacement"), [oxygen support](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxygen_support "Oxygen support") and [prone positioning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prone_positioning "Prone positioning"), and medications or devices to support other affected vital organs.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-148) More severe cases may need treatment in hospital. In those with low oxygen levels, use of the glucocorticoid [dexamethasone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dexamethasone "Dexamethasone") is recommended to reduce mortality.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-149)[Noninvasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noninvasive_ventilation "Noninvasive ventilation") and, ultimately, admission to an [intensive care unit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit "Intensive care unit") for [mechanical ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_ventilation "Mechanical ventilation") may be required to support breathing.[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NIHGuidelines2020-150)[Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extracorporeal_membrane_oxygenation "Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation") (ECMO) has been used to address the issue of respiratory failure.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Guan_Ni_Hu_Liang_p.-151)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Henry_2020_p.-152)

Existing drugs such as [hydroxychloroquine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroxychloroquine "Hydroxychloroquine"), [lopinavir/ritonavir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lopinavir/ritonavir "Lopinavir/ritonavir"), and [ivermectin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivermectin "Ivermectin") are not recommended by US or European health authorities, as there is no good evidence they have any useful effect.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Kim_Read_Fauci_p=2149-153)[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NIHGuidelinesTherapeuticManagement-154) The antiviral [remdesivir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remdesivir "Remdesivir") is available in the US, Canada, Australia, and several other countries, with varying restrictions; however, it is not recommended for use with mechanical ventilation, and is discouraged altogether by the WHO,[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hsu_p=m4457-155) due to limited evidence of its efficacy.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)

triples.sentence: For the first two years of the pandemic, no specific and effective treatment or cure was available.[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BMJLivingReview-141)[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cdcmuseum-142)
triples.statement: For the first two years of the pandemic, no specific and effective treatment or cure for COVID-19 was available.

triples.sentence: In 2021, the European Medicines Agency's (EMA) Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use (CHMP) approved the oral antiviral [protease inhibitor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protease_inhibitor_(pharmacology) "Protease inhibitor (pharmacology)"), [Paxlovid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxlovid "Paxlovid") (nirmatrelvir plus the HIV antiviral [ritonavir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ritonavir "Ritonavir")), to treat adult patients.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-143)
triples.statement: The European Medicines Agency's CHMP approved the oral antiviral protease inhibitor Paxlovid in 2021 to treat adult patients.

triples.sentence: Good personal hygiene and a [healthy diet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthy_diet "Healthy diet") are also recommended.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-147)
triples.statement: Good personal hygiene and a healthy diet are also recommended.

triples.sentence: [Supportive care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supportive_care "Supportive care") in severe cases includes treatment to [relieve symptoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symptomatic_treatment "Symptomatic treatment"), [fluid therapy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fluid_replacement "Fluid replacement"), [oxygen support](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxygen_support "Oxygen support") and [prone positioning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prone_positioning "Prone positioning"), and medications or devices to support other affected vital organs.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-148)
triples.statement: Supportive care for severe cases includes symptom relief, fluid therapy, oxygen support, prone positioning, and support for other vital organs.

triples.sentence: In those with low oxygen levels, use of the glucocorticoid [dexamethasone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dexamethasone "Dexamethasone") is recommended to reduce mortality.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-149)
triples.statement: The use of the glucocorticoid dexamethasone is recommended to reduce mortality in patients with low oxygen levels.

section_body:
Further information: [COVID-19 §Prognosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19#Prognosis "COVID-19"), and [Long COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_COVID "Long COVID")

The severity of COVID-19 varies. It may take a mild course with few or no symptoms, resembling other common upper respiratory diseases such as the [common cold](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_cold "Common cold"). In 3–4% of cases (7.4% for those over age 65) symptoms are severe enough to cause hospitalisation.[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid33087398-156) Mild cases typically recover within two weeks, while those with severe or critical diseases may take three to six weeks to recover. Among those who have died, the time from symptom onset to death has ranged from two to eight weeks. Prolonged [prothrombin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prothrombin "Prothrombin") time and elevated [C-reactive protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C-reactive_protein "C-reactive protein") levels on admission to the hospital are associated with severe course of COVID-19 and with a transfer to [intensive care units](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit "Intensive care unit") (ICU).[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-157)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-158)

Between 5% and 50% of COVID-19 patients experience [long COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_COVID "Long COVID"),[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-159) a condition characterised by long-term [consequences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequela "Sequela") persisting after the typical convalescence period of the disease.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-160)[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-161) The most commonly reported clinical presentations are [fatigue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fatigue "Fatigue") and memory problems, as well as [malaise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaise "Malaise"), headaches, [shortness of breath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortness_of_breath "Shortness of breath"), loss of smell, [muscle weakness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muscle_weakness "Muscle weakness"), low fever and [cognitive dysfunction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_dysfunction "Cognitive dysfunction").[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ref1-162)[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-163)[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-164)[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-165)

triples.sentence: Prolonged [prothrombin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prothrombin "Prothrombin") time and elevated [C-reactive protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C-reactive_protein "C-reactive protein") levels on admission to the hospital are associated with severe course of COVID-19 and with a transfer to [intensive care units](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care_unit "Intensive care unit") (ICU).[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-157)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-158)
triples.statement: Prolonged prothrombin time and elevated C-reactive protein levels upon hospital admission are linked to a severe course of COVID-19 and transfer to an ICU.

triples.sentence: Between 5% and 50% of COVID-19 patients experience [long COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_COVID "Long COVID"),[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-159) a condition characterised by long-term [consequences](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sequela "Sequela") persisting after the typical convalescence period of the disease.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-160)[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-161)
triples.statement: Between 5% and 50% of COVID-19 patients experience long COVID, a condition defined by long-term consequences that persist beyond the typical recovery period.

section_body:
Main article: [Public health mitigation of COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_health_mitigation_of_COVID-19 "Public health mitigation of COVID-19")

[![Image 34](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif/500px-20200410_Flatten_the_curve%2C_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_%28English%29.gif)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:20200410_Flatten_the_curve,_raise_the_line_-_pandemic_(English).gif)

Goals of mitigation include delaying and reducing peak burden on healthcare (_[flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening\_the\_curve "Flattening the curve")_) and lessening overall cases and health impact.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166)[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-RnW59-167) Moreover, progressively greater increases in healthcare capacity (_[raising the line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raising\_the\_line "Raising the line")_) such as by increasing bed count, personnel, and equipment, help to meet increased demand[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Vox_20200407-168)

Many countries attempted to slow or stop the spread of COVID-19 by recommending, mandating or prohibiting behaviour changes, while others relied primarily on providing information. Measures ranged from public advisories to stringent lockdowns. Outbreak control strategies are divided into elimination and mitigation. Experts differentiate between elimination strategies (known as "[zero-COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID")") that aim to completely stop the spread of the virus within the community,[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Barcelona-169) and mitigation strategies (commonly known as "[flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening_the_curve "Flattening the curve")") that attempt to lessen the effects of the virus on society, but which still tolerate some level of transmission within the community.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Livermore-170) These initial strategies can be pursued sequentially or simultaneously during the [acquired immunity phase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquired_immunity "Acquired immunity") through natural and [vaccine-induced immunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine "COVID-19 vaccine").[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Bhopal2020-171)

_Nature_ reported in 2021 that 90% of researchers who responded to a survey "think that the coronavirus will become [endemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endemic_(epidemiology) "Endemic (epidemiology)")".[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-172)

triples.sentence: Goals of mitigation include delaying and reducing peak burden on healthcare (_[flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening\_the\_curve "Flattening the curve")_) and lessening overall cases and health impact.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166)[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-RnW59-167)
triples.statement: Mitigation goals include delaying and reducing the peak burden on healthcare (flattening the curve) and lessening overall cases and health impacts.

triples.sentence: Moreover, progressively greater increases in healthcare capacity (_[raising the line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raising\_the\_line "Raising the line")_) such as by increasing bed count, personnel, and equipment, help to meet increased demand[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Vox_20200407-168)
triples.statement: Increasing healthcare capacity by adding more beds, personnel, and equipment, a strategy known as "raising the line," helps to meet increased demand.

triples.sentence: Experts differentiate between elimination strategies (known as "[zero-COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID")") that aim to completely stop the spread of the virus within the community,[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Barcelona-169) and mitigation strategies (commonly known as "[flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening_the_curve "Flattening the curve")") that attempt to lessen the effects of the virus on society, but which still tolerate some level of transmission within the community.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Livermore-170)
triples.statement: Experts distinguish between elimination strategies ("zero-COVID"), which aim to completely stop community spread, and mitigation strategies ("flattening the curve"), which try to reduce the virus's societal effects while tolerating some transmission.

triples.sentence: These initial strategies can be pursued sequentially or simultaneously during the [acquired immunity phase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acquired_immunity "Acquired immunity") through natural and [vaccine-induced immunity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine "COVID-19 vaccine").[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Bhopal2020-171)
triples.statement: These initial strategies can be pursued sequentially or at the same time during the acquired immunity phase, which is achieved through natural and vaccine-induced immunity.

section_body:
Further information: [Zero-COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID")

Containment is undertaken to stop an outbreak from spreading into the general population. Infected individuals are isolated while they are infectious. The people they have interacted with are contacted and isolated for long enough to ensure that they are either not infected or no longer contagious. Screening is the starting point for containment. Screening is done by checking for symptoms to identify infected individuals, who can then be isolated or offered treatment.[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-f4SpW-173) The zero-COVID strategy involves using public health measures such as [contact tracing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_tracing "Contact tracing"), [mass testing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_testing "COVID-19 testing"), [border quarantine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Travel during the COVID-19 pandemic"), [lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns "COVID-19 lockdowns"), and [mitigation software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Use_and_development_of_software_for_COVID-19_pandemic_mitigation "Use and development of software for COVID-19 pandemic mitigation") to stop [community transmission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19 "Transmission of COVID-19") of COVID-19 as soon as it is detected, with the goal of getting the area back to zero detected infections and resuming normal economic and social activities.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Barcelona-169)[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet-Li-2020-174) Successful containment or suppression reduces [Rt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_reproduction_number#Effective_reproduction_number "Basic reproduction number") to less than 1.[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ImpCollege16mar2020-175)

triples.sentence: The zero-COVID strategy involves using public health measures such as [contact tracing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_tracing "Contact tracing"), [mass testing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_testing "COVID-19 testing"), [border quarantine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Travel during the COVID-19 pandemic"), [lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns "COVID-19 lockdowns"), and [mitigation software](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Use_and_development_of_software_for_COVID-19_pandemic_mitigation "Use and development of software for COVID-19 pandemic mitigation") to stop [community transmission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmission_of_COVID-19 "Transmission of COVID-19") of COVID-19 as soon as it is detected, with the goal of getting the area back to zero detected infections and resuming normal economic and social activities.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Barcelona-169)[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet-Li-2020-174)
triples.statement: The zero-COVID strategy employs public health measures like contact tracing, mass testing, border quarantine, lockdowns, and software to halt community transmission of COVID-19 upon detection, aiming to reach zero infections and resume normal activities.

section_body:
Further information: [Flattening the curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flattening_the_curve "Flattening the curve")

Should containment fail, efforts focus on mitigation: measures taken to slow the spread and limit its effects on the healthcare system and society. Successful mitigation delays and decreases the epidemic peak, known as "flattening the [epidemic curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic_curve "Epidemic curve")".[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166) This decreases the risk of overwhelming health services and provides more time for developing vaccines and treatments.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166) Individual behaviour changed in many jurisdictions. Many people worked from home instead of at their traditional workplaces.[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-176)

triples.sentence: Successful mitigation delays and decreases the epidemic peak, known as "flattening the [epidemic curve](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic_curve "Epidemic curve")".[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166)
triples.statement: Successful mitigation delays and reduces the peak of an epidemic, a process known as "flattening the epidemic curve".

triples.sentence: This decreases the risk of overwhelming health services and provides more time for developing vaccines and treatments.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lancet2020Flatten-166)
triples.statement: Flattening the curve reduces the risk of overwhelming health services and allows more time for the development of vaccines and treatments.

section_body: More drastic actions, such as quarantining entire populations and strict travel bans have been attempted in various jurisdictions.[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-RwmYm-178) The [Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_government_response_to_COVID-19 "Chinese government response to COVID-19") and [Australian government approaches](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Australia#Responses "COVID-19 pandemic in Australia") have included many lockdowns and are widely considered the most strict. The [New Zealand government response](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_government_response_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "New Zealand government response to the COVID-19 pandemic") included the most severe travel restrictions. As part of its [K-Quarantine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K-Quarantine "K-Quarantine") programme, South Korea introduced mass screening and localised quarantines, and issued alerts on the movements of infected individuals. The [Singaporean government's response](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Singapore#Government_response "COVID-19 pandemic in Singapore") included so-called "[circuit breaker lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Singapore_circuit_breaker_measures "2020 Singapore circuit breaker measures")" and financial support for those affected while also imposing large fines for those who broke quarantine.[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-shZdf-179)

triples.sentence: More drastic actions, such as quarantining entire populations and strict travel bans have been attempted in various jurisdictions.[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-RwmYm-178)
triples.statement: Drastic actions like quarantining entire populations and imposing strict travel bans were attempted in various jurisdictions.

triples.sentence: The [Singaporean government's response](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Singapore#Government_response "COVID-19 pandemic in Singapore") included so-called "[circuit breaker lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_Singapore_circuit_breaker_measures "2020 Singapore circuit breaker measures")" and financial support for those affected while also imposing large fines for those who broke quarantine.[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-shZdf-179)
triples.statement: Singapore's government response included "circuit breaker lockdowns," financial support for those affected, and large fines for quarantine violations.

section_body:
See also: [Use and development of software for COVID-19 pandemic mitigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Use_and_development_of_software_for_COVID-19_pandemic_mitigation "Use and development of software for COVID-19 pandemic mitigation") and [Public health mitigation of COVID-19 §Information technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_health_mitigation_of_COVID-19#Information_technology "Public health mitigation of COVID-19")

[Contact tracing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_tracing "Contact tracing") attempts to identify recent contacts of newly infected individuals, and to screen them for infection; the traditional approach is to request a list of contacts from infectees, and then telephone or visit the contacts.[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-web-180) Contact tracing was widely used during the [Western African Ebola virus epidemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_African_Ebola_virus_epidemic "Western African Ebola virus epidemic") in 2014.[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-181)

Another approach is to collect location data from mobile devices to identify those who have come in significant contact with infectees, which prompted privacy concerns.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-IngramWard20200407-182) On 10 April 2020, Google and [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") announced an initiative for privacy-preserving contact tracing.[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-0DF25-183)[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200410apple-184) In Europe and in the US, [Palantir Technologies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palantir_Technologies "Palantir Technologies") initially provided COVID-19 tracking services.[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-0k3hR-185)

triples.sentence: [Contact tracing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contact_tracing "Contact tracing") attempts to identify recent contacts of newly infected individuals, and to screen them for infection; the traditional approach is to request a list of contacts from infectees, and then telephone or visit the contacts.[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-web-180)
triples.statement: Contact tracing seeks to identify and screen recent contacts of newly infected people, with the traditional method involving requesting a contact list from the infected individual and then calling or visiting those contacts.

triples.sentence: Contact tracing was widely used during the [Western African Ebola virus epidemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_African_Ebola_virus_epidemic "Western African Ebola virus epidemic") in 2014.[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-181)
triples.statement: Contact tracing was used extensively during the 2014 Western African Ebola virus epidemic.

triples.sentence: Another approach is to collect location data from mobile devices to identify those who have come in significant contact with infectees, which prompted privacy concerns.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-IngramWard20200407-182)
triples.statement: An alternative approach to contact tracing involves collecting location data from mobile devices to identify significant contacts of infected individuals, which has led to privacy concerns.

triples.sentence: On 10 April 2020, Google and [Apple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") announced an initiative for privacy-preserving contact tracing.[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-0DF25-183)[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200410apple-184)
triples.statement: On April 10, 2020, Google and Apple announced an initiative for contact tracing that preserves privacy.

triples.sentence: In Europe and in the US, [Palantir Technologies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palantir_Technologies "Palantir Technologies") initially provided COVID-19 tracking services.[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-0k3hR-185)
triples.statement: In Europe and the US, Palantir Technologies was an initial provider of COVID-19 tracking services.

section_body:
[![Image 36](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/COVID-19_patient_wearing_scuba_mask_in_absence_of_available_artificial_lung_ventilation._Chernivtsi%2C_Ukraine.jpg/250px-COVID-19_patient_wearing_scuba_mask_in_absence_of_available_artificial_lung_ventilation._Chernivtsi%2C_Ukraine.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:COVID-19_patient_wearing_scuba_mask_in_absence_of_available_artificial_lung_ventilation._Chernivtsi,_Ukraine.jpg)

A patient in Ukraine in 2020 wearing a [scuba mask](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diving_mask "Diving mask") in the absence of [artificial ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_ventilation "Artificial ventilation")

Due to [supply chain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain "Supply chain") capacity limitations, some manufacturers began [3D printing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3D_printing "3D printing") material such as nasal swabs and ventilator parts.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-technologyreview615420-189)[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-aCPem-190) In one example, an Italian startup received legal threats due to alleged [patent infringement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patent_infringement "Patent infringement") after reverse-engineering and printing one hundred requested ventilator valves overnight.[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-191) Individuals and groups of [makers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maker_culture "Maker culture") created and shared [open source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source "Open source") designs, and manufacturing devices using locally sourced materials, sewing, and 3D printing. Millions of [face shields](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_shield "Face shield"), protective gowns, and masks were made. Other ad hoc medical supplies included shoe covers, surgical caps, [powered air-purifying respirators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Powered_air-purifying_respirator "Powered air-purifying respirator"), and [hand sanitiser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hand_sanitiser "Hand sanitiser"). Novel devices were created such as [ear savers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ear_saver "Ear saver"), [non-invasive ventilation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-invasive_ventilation "Non-invasive ventilation") helmets, and ventilator splitters.[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-192)

triples.statement: An Italian startup received legal threats for alleged patent infringement after reverse-engineering and printing one hundred requested ventilator valves overnight.

section_body:
Main article: [Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2019](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_2019 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2019")

The [outbreak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outbreak "Outbreak") was discovered in Wuhan in November 2019. It is possible that human-to-human transmission was happening before the discovery.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hu2020natureReviews-38)[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Graham2020immunity-39) Based on a retrospective analysis starting from December 2019, the number of cases in Hubei gradually increased, reaching 60 by 20 December and at least 266 by 31 December.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-original_report-195) A [pneumonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pneumonia "Pneumonia") cluster was observed on 26 December and treated by Chinese pulmonologist [Zhang Jixian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Jixian "Zhang Jixian"). She informed the Wuhan Jianghan CDC on 27 December.[[195]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-D54YB-196) After analysing pneumonia patient samples, a genetic sequencing company named Vision Medicals reported the discovery of a [novel coronavirus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Novel_coronavirus "Novel coronavirus") to the [China CDC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Center_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention") (CCDC) on 28 December.[[196]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AP_OR-197)[[197]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-caixintrace-198) Two days later, a test report from CapitalBio Medlab addressed to the [Wuhan Central Hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Hospital_of_Wuhan "Central Hospital of Wuhan") reported an erroneous positive result for [SARS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS "SARS"), causing doctors there to alert authorities. Eight of those doctors, including ophthalmologist [Li Wenliang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li_Wenliang "Li Wenliang") (1985–2020), were detained by police on 3 January for "spreading false rumours".[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-siStf-199) That evening, Wuhan Municipal Health Commission (WMHC) issued a notice about "the treatment of pneumonia of unknown cause".[[199]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-promedmail6864153-200) The next day, WMHC made the announcement public, confirming 27 cases[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-69-201)[[201]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-68-202)—enough to trigger an investigation.[[202]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc50984025-203) On 31 December, the WHO office in China was notified about the cluster of unknown pneumonia cases[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_report-21)[[200]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-69-201) and immediately launched an investigation.[[202]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc50984025-203)

Official Chinese sources claimed that the early cases were mostly linked to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market, which also sold live animals.[[203]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-characteristicsZH-204) In May 2020, CCDC director George Gao initially ruled out the market as a possible origin, as animal samples collected there had tested negative.[[204]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ALmAQ-205)

triples.sentence: It is possible that human-to-human transmission was happening before the discovery.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hu2020natureReviews-38)[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Graham2020immunity-39)
triples.statement: Human-to-human transmission may have been occurring before the outbreak was discovered.

triples.sentence: Based on a retrospective analysis starting from December 2019, the number of cases in Hubei gradually increased, reaching 60 by 20 December and at least 266 by 31 December.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-original_report-195)
triples.statement: A retrospective analysis indicated that by December 2019, cases in Hubei had increased to 60 by December 20 and at least 266 by December 31.

triples.sentence: Eight of those doctors, including ophthalmologist [Li Wenliang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Li_Wenliang "Li Wenliang") (1985–2020), were detained by police on 3 January for "spreading false rumours".[[198]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-siStf-199)
triples.statement: On January 3, eight doctors, including ophthalmologist Li Wenliang, were detained by police for "spreading false rumours".

section_body:
Timelines of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 by month: [January](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_January_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in January 2020"), [February](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_February_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in February 2020"), [March](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_March_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020"), [April](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_April_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in April 2020"), [May](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_May_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in May 2020"), [June](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_June_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in June 2020"), [July](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_July_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in July 2020"), [August](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_August_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in August 2020"), [September](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_September_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in September 2020"), [October](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_October_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in October 2020"), [November](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_November_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in November 2020"), [December](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_December_2020 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in December 2020")

[![Image 37](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/COVID-19_highway_sign_in_Toronto%2C_March_2020.jpg/250px-COVID-19_highway_sign_in_Toronto%2C_March_2020.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:COVID-19_highway_sign_in_Toronto,_March_2020.jpg)

A highway sign discouraging travel in [Toronto](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto "Toronto"), March 2020

On 11 January, WHO was notified by the Chinese National Health Commission that the outbreak was associated with exposures in the market, and that China had identified a new type of coronavirus, which it isolated on 7 January.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_report-21)

Initially, the number of cases doubled approximately every seven and a half days.[[205]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Qun29Jan2020-206) In early and mid-January, the virus spread to other [Chinese provinces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_China "Provinces of China"), helped by the [Chinese New Year migration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chunyun "Chunyun"). Wuhan was a transport hub and major rail interchange.[[206]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_report_28_February_2020-207) On 10 January, the virus' genome was shared publicly.[[207]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-208) A retrospective study published in March found that 6,174 people had reported symptoms by 20 January.[[208]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Epidemiology17Feb2020-209) A 24 January report indicated human transmission was likely occurring, and recommended [personal protective equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_protective_equipment "Personal protective equipment") for health workers. It also advocated testing, given the outbreak's "pandemic potential".[[209]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Huang24Jan2020-210)[[210]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Horton_18_March-211) On 30 January, 7,818 infections had been confirmed, leading WHO to declare the outbreak a [Public Health Emergency of International Concern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Health_Emergency_of_International_Concern "Public Health Emergency of International Concern") (PHEIC),[[211]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_PHEICSR-212)[[212]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_PHEIC_decl2-213)[[213]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-214) upgrading it to a pandemic on 11 March.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-start-3) On 31 January, the first published modelling study warned of inevitable "independent self-sustaining outbreaks in major cities globally" and called for "large-scale public health interventions".[[214]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-pmid32014114-215)

By 31 January, Italy indicated its first confirmed infections had occurred, in two tourists from China.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Corriere_20Jan-216) The WHO announced on 11 March its assessment that the situation could be characterised as a pandemic.[[3]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-start-3) On 19 March, Italy overtook China as the country with the most reported deaths.[[216]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-sky11960412-217)

By 26 March, the United States had overtaken China and Italy as the country with the highest number of confirmed infections.[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT-20200326-218) Genomic analysis indicated that the majority of [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_York_(state) "COVID-19 pandemic in New York (state)")'s confirmed infections came from Europe, rather than directly from Asia.[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200408nytimes-219) Testing of prior samples revealed a person who was infected in France on 27 December 2019[[219]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-France-retest-220)[[220]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Deslandes_2020-221) and a person in the United States who died from the disease on 6 February.[[221]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-PBS-2wks-222)

[![Image 38](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Covid-19_San_Salvatore_09.jpg/250px-Covid-19_San_Salvatore_09.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Covid-19_San_Salvatore_09.jpg)

An exhausted [anaesthesiologist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anesthesiology "Anesthesiology") in [Pesaro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pesaro "Pesaro"), Italy, 19 March 2020

In October, WHO reported that one in ten people around the world may have been infected, or 780 million people, while only 35 million infections had been confirmed.[[222]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_oneinten-223)

On 9 November, Pfizer released trial results for a candidate vaccine, showing a 90 per cent effectiveness in preventing infection. That day, Novavax submitted an FDA Fast Track application for their vaccine.[[223]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-FEv4C-224)[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NPZ5P-225) On 14 December, [Public Health England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Health_England "Public Health England") reported that a variant had been discovered in the UK's southeast, predominantly in [Kent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kent "Kent"). The variant, later named [Alpha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variant_of_Concern_202012/01 "Variant of Concern 202012/01"), showed changes to the [spike protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus_spike_protein "Coronavirus spike protein") that could make the virus more infectious. As of 13 December, 1,108 infections had been confirmed in the UK.[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-226)[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-227) On 4 February 2020, US Secretary of Health and Human Services [Alex Azar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Azar "Alex Azar") waived liability for vaccine manufacturers in all cases except those involving "willful misconduct".[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mXTUz-228)[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-229)

triples.sentence: By 26 March, the United States had overtaken China and Italy as the country with the highest number of confirmed infections.[[217]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT-20200326-218)
triples.statement: By March 26, the United States had surpassed China and Italy as the country with the highest number of confirmed infections.

triples.sentence: Genomic analysis indicated that the majority of [New York](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_York_(state) "COVID-19 pandemic in New York (state)")'s confirmed infections came from Europe, rather than directly from Asia.[[218]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200408nytimes-219)
triples.statement: Genomic analysis indicated that most of New York's confirmed infections came from Europe, rather than directly from Asia.

triples.sentence: In October, WHO reported that one in ten people around the world may have been infected, or 780 million people, while only 35 million infections had been confirmed.[[222]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_oneinten-223)
triples.statement: In October, the WHO reported that an estimated one in ten people worldwide (780 million) may have been infected, while only 35 million infections had been confirmed.

triples.sentence: That day, Novavax submitted an FDA Fast Track application for their vaccine.[[223]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-FEv4C-224)[[224]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NPZ5P-225)
triples.statement: On the same day, Novavax submitted an FDA Fast Track application for their vaccine.

triples.sentence: As of 13 December, 1,108 infections had been confirmed in the UK.[[225]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-226)[[226]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-227)
triples.statement: As of December 13, 1,108 infections of the new variant had been confirmed in the UK.

triples.sentence: On 4 February 2020, US Secretary of Health and Human Services [Alex Azar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Azar "Alex Azar") waived liability for vaccine manufacturers in all cases except those involving "willful misconduct".[[227]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mXTUz-228)[[228]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-229)
triples.statement: On February 4, 2020, US Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar waived liability for vaccine manufacturers in all cases except those involving "willful misconduct".

Timelines of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2021 by month: [January](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_January_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in January 2021"), [February](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_February_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in February 2021"), [March](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_March_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2021"), [April](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_April_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in April 2021"), [May](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_May_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in May 2021"), [June](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_June_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in June 2021"), [July](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_July_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in July 2021"), [August](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_August_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in August 2021"), [September](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_September_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in September 2021"), [October](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_October_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in October 2021"), [November](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_November_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in November 2021"), [December](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_December_2021 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in December 2021")

On 2 January, the [Alpha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Alpha_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Alpha variant") variant, first discovered in the UK, had been identified in 33 countries.[[229]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-230) On 6 January, the [Gamma variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lineage_P.1 "Lineage P.1") was first identified in Japanese travellers returning from Brazil.[[230]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-231) On 29 January, it was reported that the Novavax vaccine was 49 per cent effective against the [Beta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Beta_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Beta variant") variant in a clinical trial in South Africa.[[231]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-232)[[232]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-233) The [CoronaVac vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoronaVac_vaccine "CoronaVac vaccine") was reported to be 50.4 per cent effective in a Brazil clinical trial.[[233]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-234)

[![Image 39](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Covid-19_SP_-_Santo_Andre%27s_hospital_at_peak_of_pandemic.jpg/250px-Covid-19_SP_-_Santo_Andre%27s_hospital_at_peak_of_pandemic.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Covid-19_SP_-_Santo_Andre%27s_hospital_at_peak_of_pandemic.jpg)

A temporary hospital for COVID-19 patients in [Santo André](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santo_Andr%C3%A9,_S%C3%A3o_Paulo "Santo André, São Paulo"), Brazil, in March 2021

On 12 March, several countries stopped using the [Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford%E2%80%93AstraZeneca_COVID-19_vaccine "Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine") due to blood clotting problems, specifically [cerebral venous sinus thrombosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cerebral_venous_sinus_thrombosis "Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis") (CVST).[[234]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-235) On 20 March, the WHO and European Medicines Agency found no link to [thrombosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thrombosis "Thrombosis"), leading several countries to resume administering the vaccine.[[235]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-236) In March WHO reported that an animal host was the most likely origin, without ruling out other possibilities.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-who-origins-20210330-2)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Maxmen2021whoReport-37) The [Delta variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Delta_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Delta variant") was first identified in India. In mid-April, the variant was first detected in the UK and two months later it had become a full-fledged third wave in the country, forcing the government to delay reopening that was originally scheduled for June.[[236]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-237) On 10 November, Germany advised against the [Moderna vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moderna_COVID-19_vaccine "Moderna COVID-19 vaccine") for people under 30, due to a possible association with [myocarditis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myocarditis "Myocarditis").[[237]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-238) On 24 November, the [Omicron variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant") was detected in South Africa; a few days later the WHO declared it a VoC (variant of concern).[[238]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-239) The new variant is more infectious than the Delta variant.[[239]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-240)

triples.statement: By 2 January, the Alpha variant, first discovered in the UK, had been identified in 33 countries.

triples.statement: The Gamma variant was first identified on 6 January in Japanese travellers returning from Brazil.

triples.statement: On 20 March, the WHO and European Medicines Agency found no link to thrombosis, which led several countries to resume administering the vaccine.

triples.sentence: In March WHO reported that an animal host was the most likely origin, without ruling out other possibilities.[[2]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-who-origins-20210330-2)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Maxmen2021whoReport-37)
triples.statement: In March, the WHO reported that an animal host was the most likely origin of the virus, without ruling out other possibilities.

triples.statement: On 10 November, Germany advised against the Moderna vaccine for people under 30 because of a possible association with myocarditis.

triples.statement: The Omicron variant was detected in South Africa on 24 November, and a few days later the WHO declared it a variant of concern (VoC).
