section_body:
[![Image 40](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Novel_Coronavirus_SARS-CoV-2_%28Omicron%29_%2852665469105%29.jpg/250px-Novel_Coronavirus_SARS-CoV-2_%28Omicron%29_%2852665469105%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Novel_Coronavirus_SARS-CoV-2_(Omicron)_(52665469105).jpg)

Scanning electron micrograph (colorised) of cell infected with the Omicron strain of SARS-CoV-2 virus particles _green_

Timelines of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2022 by month: [January](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_January_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in January 2022"), [February](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_February_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in February 2022"), [March](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_March_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2022"), [April](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_April_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in April 2022"), [May](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_May_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in May 2022"), [June](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_June_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in June 2022"), [July](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_July_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in July 2022"), [August](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_August_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in August 2022"), [September](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_September_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in September 2022"), [October](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_October_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in October 2022"), [November](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_November_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in November 2022"), [December](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_December_2022 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in December 2022")

On 1 January, Europe passed 100 million cases amidst a surge in the [Omicron variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant").[[240]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-241) Later that month, the WHO recommended the [rheumatoid arthritis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rheumatoid_arthritis "Rheumatoid arthritis") drug [Baricitinib](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baricitinib "Baricitinib") for severe or critical patients. It also recommended the monoclonal antibody [Sotrovimab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sotrovimab "Sotrovimab") in patients with non-severe disease, but only those who are at highest risk of hospitalisation.[[241]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-242)

On 24 January, the [Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_Health_Metrics_and_Evaluation "Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation") estimated that about 57% of the world's population had been infected by COVID-19.[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-57percent1-64)[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-57percent2-65) By 6 March, it was reported that the total worldwide death count had surpassed 6 million people.[[242]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-243) By 6 July, Omicron subvariants [BA.4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BA.4 "BA.4") and [BA.5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BA.5 "BA.5") had spread worldwide.[[243]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-244) WHO Director-General Tedros Ghebreyesus stated on 14 September 2022, that "[The world has] never been in a better position to end the pandemic", citing the lowest number of weekly reported deaths since March 2020. He continued, "We are not there yet. But the end is in sight—we can see the finish line".[[244]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-245)[[245]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-246)[[246]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-247)[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-248)

On 21 October, the United States surpassed 99 million cases of COVID-19, the most cases of any country.[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-249) By 30 October, the worldwide daily death toll was 424, the lowest since 385 deaths were reported on 12 March 2020.[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-250) 17 November marked the three-year anniversary since health officials in China first detected COVID-19.[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-251)

On 11 November, the WHO reported that deaths since the month of February had dropped 90 per cent. Director-General Tedros said this was "cause for optimism".[[251]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-252) On 3 December, the WHO indicated that, "at least 90% of the world's population has some level of immunity to Sars-CoV-2".[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-253) In early December, China began lifting some of its most stringent lockdown measures. Subsequent data from China's health authorities revealed that 248 million people, nearly 18 per cent of its population, had been infected in the first 20 days of that month.[[253]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-254) On 29 December, the US joined Italy, Japan, Taiwan and India in requiring negative COVID-19 test results from all people travelling from China due to the new surge in cases. The EU refused similar measures, stating that the BF7 omicron variant had already spread throughout Europe without becoming dominant.[[254]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-255)[[255]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-256)

triples.sentence: On 1 January, Europe passed 100 million cases amidst a surge in the [Omicron variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant").[[240]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-241)
triples.statement: On January 1, 2022, Europe surpassed 100 million COVID-19 cases during a surge of the Omicron variant.

triples.sentence: By 6 March, it was reported that the total worldwide death count had surpassed 6 million people.[[242]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-243)
triples.statement: By March 6, 2022, the total worldwide death count from COVID-19 was reported to have surpassed 6 million.

triples.sentence: On 21 October, the United States surpassed 99 million cases of COVID-19, the most cases of any country.[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-249)
triples.statement: On October 21, 2022, the United States surpassed 99 million COVID-19 cases, the highest number of any country.

triples.sentence: By 30 October, the worldwide daily death toll was 424, the lowest since 385 deaths were reported on 12 March 2020.[[249]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-250)
triples.statement: By October 30, 2022, the global daily death toll from COVID-19 was 424, the lowest figure since March 12, 2020.

triples.sentence: 17 November marked the three-year anniversary since health officials in China first detected COVID-19.[[250]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-251)
triples.statement: November 17, 2022, was the three-year anniversary of the first detection of COVID-19 by health officials in China.

triples.sentence: On 3 December, the WHO indicated that, "at least 90% of the world's population has some level of immunity to Sars-CoV-2".[[252]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-253)
triples.statement: On December 3, 2022, the WHO indicated that at least 90% of the global population had some level of immunity to SARS-CoV-2.

section_body:
[Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2023](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_2023 "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2023")

On 4 January 2023, the WHO said the information shared by China during the recent surge in infections lacked data, such as hospitalisation rates.[[256]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-257) On 10 January, the WHO's Europe office said the recent viral surge in China posed "no immediate threat."[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-258) On 16 January, the WHO recommended that China monitor excess mortality to provide "a more comprehensive understanding of the impact of COVID-19".[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-259)

On 30 January, the three-year anniversary of the original declaration, the WHO determined that COVID-19 still met the criteria for a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC).[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-260)

On 19 March, WHO Director-General Tedros indicated he was "confident" the COVID-19 pandemic would cease to be a public health emergency by the end of the year.[[260]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-261) On 5 May, the WHO downgraded COVID-19 from being a global health emergency, though it continued to refer to it as a pandemic.[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-262) The WHO does not make official declarations of when pandemics end.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters-4)[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-guardian-263) The decision came after Tedros convened with the International Health Regulations Emergency Committee, wherein the Committee noted that due to the decrease in deaths and hospitalisations, and the prevalence of vaccinations and the level of general immunity, it was time to remove the emergency designation and "transition to long-term management".[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Statement_5_May_2023-264) Tedros agreed, and the WHO reduced the classification to an "established and ongoing health issue".[[263]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Statement_5_May_2023-264) In a press conference, Tedros remarked that the diminishing threat from COVID-19 had "allowed most countries to return to life as we knew it before COVID-19".[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-npr-265)

In September the WHO said it had observed "concerning" trends in COVID-19 case numbers and hospitalisations, although analysis was hampered because many countries were no longer recording COVID-19 case statistics.[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-266)

In November 2023, in response to viral mutations and changing characteristics of infection, the WHO adjusted its treatment guidelines. Among other changes, remdesivir and molnupiravir were now recommended only for the most severe cases, and [deuremidevir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deuremidevir "Deuremidevir") and ivermectin were recommended against.[[266]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-267)

triples.sentence: On 10 January, the WHO's Europe office said the recent viral surge in China posed "no immediate threat."[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-258)
triples.statement: The WHO's Europe office stated on January 10 that the recent viral surge in China did not pose an "immediate threat."

triples.sentence: On 16 January, the WHO recommended that China monitor excess mortality to provide "a more comprehensive understanding of the impact of COVID-19".[[258]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-259)
triples.statement: On January 16, the WHO recommended that China should monitor its excess mortality to better understand the impact of COVID-19.

triples.sentence: On 30 January, the three-year anniversary of the original declaration, the WHO determined that COVID-19 still met the criteria for a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC).[[259]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-260)
triples.statement: On January 30, three years after its initial declaration, the WHO confirmed that COVID-19 still qualified as a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC).

triples.sentence: On 5 May, the WHO downgraded COVID-19 from being a global health emergency, though it continued to refer to it as a pandemic.[[261]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-262)
triples.statement: On May 5, the WHO downgraded COVID-19 from a global health emergency, but still considered it a pandemic.

triples.sentence: The WHO does not make official declarations of when pandemics end.[[4]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters-4)[[262]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-guardian-263)
triples.statement: The WHO does not officially declare when pandemics are over.

triples.sentence: In a press conference, Tedros remarked that the diminishing threat from COVID-19 had "allowed most countries to return to life as we knew it before COVID-19".[[264]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-npr-265)
triples.statement: In a press conference, WHO Director-General Tedros stated that the reduced threat from COVID-19 had enabled most countries to resume pre-pandemic life.

triples.sentence: In September the WHO said it had observed "concerning" trends in COVID-19 case numbers and hospitalisations, although analysis was hampered because many countries were no longer recording COVID-19 case statistics.[[265]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-266)
triples.statement: In September, the WHO reported observing "concerning" trends in COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations, but noted that analysis was difficult as many countries had stopped recording case statistics.

section_body:
Main articles: [COVID-19 lockdowns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns "COVID-19 lockdowns"), [COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_by_country_and_territory "COVID-19 pandemic by country and territory"), and [National responses to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "National responses to the COVID-19 pandemic")

National reactions ranged from strict lockdowns to public education campaigns.[[267]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-IVdfl-268) WHO recommended that curfews and lockdowns should be short-term measures to reorganise, regroup, rebalance resources, and protect the health care system.[[268]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-58tIM-269) As of 26 March 2020, 1.7 billion people worldwide were under some form of lockdown.[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-theguardian500000-270) This increased to 3.9 billion people by the first week of April—more than half the [world's population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_population "World population").[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200403euronews-271)[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200328businessinsider-272)

In several countries, [protests rose against restrictions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protests_against_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Protests against responses to the COVID-19 pandemic") such as lockdowns. A February 2021 study found that protests against restrictions were likely to directly increase the spread of the virus.[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-273)

triples.sentence: As of 26 March 2020, 1.7 billion people worldwide were under some form of lockdown.[[269]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-theguardian500000-270)
triples.statement: As of March 26, 2020, 1.7 billion people worldwide were under some form of lockdown.

triples.sentence: This increased to 3.9 billion people by the first week of April—more than half the [world's population](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_population "World population").[[270]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200403euronews-271)[[271]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200328businessinsider-272)
triples.statement: By the first week of April, the number of people under lockdown increased to 3.9 billion, which was more than half the world's population.

triples.sentence: A February 2021 study found that protests against restrictions were likely to directly increase the spread of the virus.[[272]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-273)
triples.statement: A study from February 2021 found that protests against restrictions were likely to directly increase the spread of the virus.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Asia "COVID-19 pandemic in Asia")

As of the end of 2021, Asia's peak had come at the same time and at the same level as the world as a whole, in May 2021.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-274) However, cumulatively they had experienced only half of the global average in cases.[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-275)

[![Image 41](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/%E5%A1%94%E5%AD%90%E6%B9%96%E4%BD%93%E8%82%B2%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E6%94%B9%E9%80%A0%E7%9A%84%E6%96%B9%E8%88%B1%E5%8C%BB%E9%99%A2_07.jpg/250px-%E5%A1%94%E5%AD%90%E6%B9%96%E4%BD%93%E8%82%B2%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E6%94%B9%E9%80%A0%E7%9A%84%E6%96%B9%E8%88%B1%E5%8C%BB%E9%99%A2_07.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:%E5%A1%94%E5%AD%90%E6%B9%96%E4%BD%93%E8%82%B2%E4%B8%AD%E5%BF%83%E6%94%B9%E9%80%A0%E7%9A%84%E6%96%B9%E8%88%B1%E5%8C%BB%E9%99%A2_07.jpg)

A [temporary hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fangcang_Hospital "Fangcang Hospital") constructed in Wuhan in February 2020

China opted for containment, instituting strict lockdowns to eliminate viral spread.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:02-276)[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-277) The vaccines distributed in China included the [BIBP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinopharm_BIBP_COVID-19_vaccine "Sinopharm BIBP COVID-19 vaccine"), [WIBP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinopharm_WIBP_COVID-19_vaccine "Sinopharm WIBP COVID-19 vaccine"), and [CoronaVac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CoronaVac "CoronaVac").[[277]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-278) It was reported on 11 December 2021, that China had vaccinated 1.162 billion of its citizens, or 82.5% of the total population of the country against COVID-19.[[278]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-279) China's large-scale adoption of [zero-COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID") had largely contained the first waves of infections of the disease.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:02-276)[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-280)[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-281) When the waves of infections due to the [Omicron variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant") followed, China was almost alone in pursuing the strategy of zero-Covid to combat the spread of the virus in 2022.[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-282) Lockdown continued to be employed in November to combat a new wave of cases;[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-283)[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-284) however, [protests erupted in cities across China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_COVID-19_protests_in_China "2022 COVID-19 protests in China") over the country's stringent measures,[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-285)[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-286) and in December that year, the country relaxed its zero-COVID policy.[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-287) On 20 December 2022, the Chinese State Council narrowed its definition of what would be counted as a COVID-19 death to include solely respiratory failure, which led to scepticism by health experts of the government's total death count[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-288)[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-289) at a time when hospitals reported being overwhelmed with cases following the abrupt discontinuation of zero-COVID.[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-290)

The first case in India was reported on 30 January 2020. India ordered a nationwide lockdown starting 24 March 2020,[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mrGsK-291) with a phased unlock beginning 1 June 2020. Six cities accounted for around half of reported cases—[Mumbai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Maharashtra "COVID-19 pandemic in Maharashtra"), [Delhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Delhi "COVID-19 pandemic in Delhi"), [Ahmedabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Gujarat "COVID-19 pandemic in Gujarat"), [Chennai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Tamil_Nadu "COVID-19 pandemic in Tamil Nadu"), [Pune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Maharashtra "COVID-19 pandemic in Maharashtra") and [Kolkata](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_West_Bengal "COVID-19 pandemic in West Bengal").[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-sHMHJ-292) Post-lockdown, the Government of India introduced a contact tracking app called [Aarogya Setu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aarogya_Setu "Aarogya Setu") to help authorities manage contact tracing and vaccine distribution.[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-293) India's vaccination programme was considered to be the world's largest and most successful with over 90% of citizens getting the first dose and another 65% getting the second dose.[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-294)[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-295) A second wave hit India in April 2021, straining healthcare services.[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-296) On 21 October 2021, it was reported that the country had surpassed 1 billion vaccinations.[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-297)

[![Image 42](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Disinfection_of_Tehran_subway_wagons_against_coronavirus_2020-02-26_09.jpg/250px-Disinfection_of_Tehran_subway_wagons_against_coronavirus_2020-02-26_09.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Disinfection_of_Tehran_subway_wagons_against_coronavirus_2020-02-26_09.jpg)

Disinfection of [Tehran Metro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tehran_Metro "Tehran Metro") trains to prevent COVID-19 transmission. Similar measures have also been taken in other countries.[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-2kQpo-298)

Iran reported its first confirmed cases on 19 February 2020, in [Qom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qom "Qom").[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wHBRB-299)[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-4yrqM-300) Early measures included the cancellation/closure of concerts and other cultural events,[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Xm5nq-301) Friday prayers,[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Urdn6-302) and school and university campuses.[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-2YX6a-303) Iran became a centre of the pandemic in February 2020.[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-HHOnl-304)[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-New_Yorker-305) More than ten countries had traced their outbreaks to Iran by 28 February, indicating a more severe outbreak than the 388 reported cases.[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-New_Yorker-305)[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-D2Xpc-306) The [Iranian Parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Consultative_Assembly "Islamic Consultative Assembly") closed, after 23 of its 290 members tested positive on 3 March 2020.[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-fXv2K-307) At least twelve sitting or former Iranian politicians and government officials had died by 17 March 2020.[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-oxtUC-308) By August 2021, the pandemic's fifth wave peaked, with more than 400 deaths in 1 day.[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-309)

COVID-19 was confirmed in South Korea on 20 January 2020. Military bases were quarantined after tests showed three infected soldiers.[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-b82186-310) South Korea introduced what was then considered the world's largest and best-organised screening programme, isolating infected people, and tracing and quarantining contacts.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-science20200317-311) Screening methods included mandatory self-reporting by new international arrivals through mobile application,[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-nbcnews1167376-312) combined with [drive-through](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drive-through "Drive-through") testing,[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CvyZS-313) and increasing testing capability to 20,000 people/day.[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-fdhQW-314) Despite some early criticisms,[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-imx38-315) South Korea's programme was considered a success in controlling the outbreak without quarantining entire cities.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-science20200317-311)[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Wypis-316)[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-joins23778577-317)

triples.sentence: As of the end of 2021, Asia's peak had come at the same time and at the same level as the world as a whole, in May 2021.[[273]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-274)
triples.statement: By the end of 2021, Asia's COVID-19 peak occurred in May 2021, aligning in time and level with the global peak.

triples.sentence: However, cumulatively they had experienced only half of the global average in cases.[[274]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-275)
triples.statement: Cumulatively, Asia had experienced only half the global average of COVID-19 cases.

triples.sentence: China opted for containment, instituting strict lockdowns to eliminate viral spread.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:02-276)[[276]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-277)
triples.statement: China implemented a containment strategy with strict lockdowns to stop the spread of the virus.

triples.sentence: China's large-scale adoption of [zero-COVID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID") had largely contained the first waves of infections of the disease.[[275]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:02-276)[[279]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-280)[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-281)
triples.statement: China's zero-COVID policy was largely successful in containing the initial waves of infection.

triples.sentence: When the waves of infections due to the [Omicron variant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SARS-CoV-2_Omicron_variant "SARS-CoV-2 Omicron variant") followed, China was almost alone in pursuing the strategy of zero-Covid to combat the spread of the virus in 2022.[[281]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-282)
triples.statement: In 2022, during the Omicron variant waves, China was one of the few countries still pursuing a zero-COVID strategy.

triples.sentence: Six cities accounted for around half of reported cases—[Mumbai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Maharashtra "COVID-19 pandemic in Maharashtra"), [Delhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Delhi "COVID-19 pandemic in Delhi"), [Ahmedabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Gujarat "COVID-19 pandemic in Gujarat"), [Chennai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Tamil_Nadu "COVID-19 pandemic in Tamil Nadu"), [Pune](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Maharashtra "COVID-19 pandemic in Maharashtra") and [Kolkata](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_West_Bengal "COVID-19 pandemic in West Bengal").[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-sHMHJ-292)

triples.statement: After the lockdown, the Indian government launched the Aarogya Setu app for contact tracing and vaccine distribution management.

triples.statement: India's vaccination program was regarded as the world's largest and most successful, with over 90% of citizens receiving a first dose and 65% receiving a second dose.

triples.sentence: A second wave hit India in April 2021, straining healthcare services.[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-296)
triples.statement: A second wave of COVID-19 in India in April 2021 put a strain on healthcare services.

triples.sentence: On 21 October 2021, it was reported that the country had surpassed 1 billion vaccinations.[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-297)
triples.statement: By October 21, 2021, India had administered over 1 billion vaccine doses.

triples.statement: Tehran Metro trains were disinfected to prevent COVID-19 transmission, a measure also adopted in other countries.

triples.sentence: Iran became a centre of the pandemic in February 2020.[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-HHOnl-304)[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-New_Yorker-305)
triples.statement: In February 2020, Iran became a center of the pandemic.

triples.sentence: More than ten countries had traced their outbreaks to Iran by 28 February, indicating a more severe outbreak than the 388 reported cases.[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-New_Yorker-305)[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-D2Xpc-306)
triples.statement: By February 28, over ten countries had traced their outbreaks to Iran, suggesting the outbreak was more severe than the 388 cases officially reported.

triples.sentence: The [Iranian Parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Consultative_Assembly "Islamic Consultative Assembly") closed, after 23 of its 290 members tested positive on 3 March 2020.[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-fXv2K-307)
triples.statement: The Iranian Parliament closed on March 3, 2020, after 23 of its 290 members tested positive for COVID-19.

triples.statement: By March 17, 2020, at least twelve current or former Iranian politicians and government officials had died from COVID-19.

triples.statement: The fifth wave of the pandemic in Iran peaked in August 2021, with over 400 deaths in a single day.

triples.statement: Military bases in South Korea were quarantined after three soldiers tested positive.

triples.sentence: South Korea introduced what was then considered the world's largest and best-organised screening programme, isolating infected people, and tracing and quarantining contacts.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-science20200317-311)
triples.statement: South Korea implemented what was considered the world's largest and most organized screening program, which involved isolating infected individuals and conducting contact tracing and quarantine.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Europe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Europe "COVID-19 pandemic in Europe")

[![Image 43](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Persons_died_due_to_coronavirus_COVID-19_per_capita_in_Europe.svg/500px-Persons_died_due_to_coronavirus_COVID-19_per_capita_in_Europe.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Persons_died_due_to_coronavirus_COVID-19_per_capita_in_Europe.svg)

Deaths per 100,000 residents

The COVID-19 pandemic arrived in Europe with its first confirmed case in [Bordeaux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bordeaux "Bordeaux"), [France](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_France "COVID-19 pandemic in France"), on 24 January 2020, and subsequently spread widely across the continent. By 17 March 2020, every country in Europe had confirmed a case,[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-318) and all had reported at least one death, with the exception of [Vatican City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Vatican_City "COVID-19 pandemic in Vatican City"). Italy was the first European nation to experience a major outbreak in early 2020, becoming the first country worldwide to introduce a national [lockdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns_in_Italy "COVID-19 lockdowns in Italy").[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-319) By 13 March 2020, the WHO declared Europe the epicentre of the pandemic[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-320)[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-321) and it remained so until the WHO announced it had been overtaken by [South America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_South_America "COVID-19 pandemic in South America") on 22 May.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-322) By 18 March 2020, more than 250 million people were in [lockdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stay-at-home_order "Stay-at-home order") in Europe.[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-323) Despite [deployment of COVID-19 vaccines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_of_COVID-19_vaccines "Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines"), Europe became the pandemic's epicentre once again in late 2021.[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-324)[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-325)

The [Italian outbreak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Italy "COVID-19 pandemic in Italy") began on 31 January 2020, when two Chinese tourists tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 in Rome.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Corriere_20Jan-216) Cases began to rise sharply, which prompted the government to suspend flights to and from China and declare a state of emergency.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-thelocal-flight-326) On 22 February 2020, the Council of Ministers announced a new decree-law to contain the outbreak, which quarantined more than 50,000 people in northern Italy.[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-201-327) On 4 March, the Italian government ordered schools and universities closed as Italy reached a hundred deaths. Sport was suspended completely for at least one month.[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Kv4Ld-328) On 11 March, Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte closed down nearly all commercial activity except supermarkets and pharmacies.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-To26Y-329)[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ClzT6-330) On 19 April, the first wave ebbed, as 7-day deaths declined to 433.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-thehill493586-331) On 13 October, the Italian government again issued restrictive rules to contain the second wave.[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-KhaW7-332) On 10 November, Italy surpassed 1 million confirmed infections.[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-8XEwk-333) On 23 November, it was reported that the second wave of the virus had led some hospitals to stop accepting patients.[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-334)

[![Image 44: Elderly woman rolls up sleeve as two nurses administer a vaccine.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/2020_12_27_mas_vacunados_en_la_residencia_mixta_1_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-2020_12_27_mas_vacunados_en_la_residencia_mixta_1_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:2020_12_27_mas_vacunados_en_la_residencia_mixta_1_(cropped).jpg)

Vaccinations at a [retirement home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retirement_home "Retirement home") in [Gijón](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gij%C3%B3n "Gijón"), Spain on 12 December 2020

The virus was first confirmed to have spread to Spain on 31 January 2020, when a German tourist tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 on [La Gomera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Gomera "La Gomera") in the Canary Islands.[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SanidadConfirmaEnLaGomera-335) Post-hoc genetic analysis has shown that at least 15 strains of the virus had been imported, and [community transmission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_transmission "Community transmission") began by mid-February.[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-genetic_analysis-336) On 29 March, it was announced that, beginning the following day, all non-essential workers were ordered to remain at home for the next 14 days.[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-337) The number of cases increased again in July in a number of cities including [Barcelona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona"), [Zaragoza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zaragoza "Zaragoza") and [Madrid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid "Madrid"), which led to reimposition of some restrictions but no national lockdown.[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc25july-338)[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-elpais6aug-339)[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-telegraph_aug16-340)[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-341) By September 2021, Spain was one of the countries with the highest percentage of its population vaccinated (76% fully vaccinated and 79% with the first dose).[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto2-342) Italy is ranked second at 75%.[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto2-342)

Sweden differed from most other European countries in that it mostly remained open.[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT20200515-343) Per the [Swedish constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swedish_constitution "Swedish constitution"), the [Public Health Agency of Sweden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Health_Agency_of_Sweden "Public Health Agency of Sweden") has autonomy that prevents political interference and the agency favoured remaining open. The Swedish strategy focused on longer-term measures, based on the assumption that after lockdown the virus would resume spreading, with the same result.[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-7ys2k-344)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-I06mN-345) By the end of June, Sweden no longer had [excess mortality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Excess_mortality "Excess mortality").[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-HEUrz-346)

[Devolution in the United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Devolution_in_the_United_Kingdom "Devolution in the United Kingdom") meant that each of its four [countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom "Countries of the United Kingdom") developed its own response. England's restrictions were shorter-lived than the others.[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-8VnMf-347) The [UK government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom "Government of the United Kingdom") started enforcing social distancing and quarantine measures on 18 March 2020.[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-PkWGD-348)[[348]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Pkx25-349) On 16 March, Prime Minister [Boris Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boris_Johnson "Boris Johnson") advised against non-essential travel and social contact, praising [work from home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_work "Remote work") and avoiding venues such as pubs, restaurants, and theatres.[[349]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-5Q93q-350)[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-hYdUy-351) On 20 March, the government ordered all leisure establishments to close,[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dmBNt-352) and promised to prevent unemployment.[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mV2p3-353) On 23 March, Johnson banned gatherings and restricted non-essential travel and outdoor activity. Unlike previous measures, these restrictions were enforceable by police through fines and dispersal of gatherings. Most non-essential businesses were ordered to close.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc-pm-2403-354) On 24 April 2020, it was reported that a promising vaccine trial had begun in England; the government pledged more than £50 million towards research.[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vKeXC-355) On 16 April 2020, it was reported that the UK would have first access to the Oxford vaccine, due to a prior contract; should the trial be successful, some 30 million doses would be available.[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Lbt4o-356) On 2 December 2020, the UK became the first developed country to approve the Pfizer vaccine; 800,000 doses were immediately available for use.[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-357) In August 2022 it was reported that viral infection cases had declined in the UK.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-358)

triples.sentence: By 17 March 2020, every country in Europe had confirmed a case,[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-318) and all had reported at least one death, with the exception of [Vatican City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Vatican_City "COVID-19 pandemic in Vatican City").
triples.statement: By March 17, 2020, every European country had confirmed a case of COVID-19, and all except Vatican City had reported at least one death.

triples.sentence: Italy was the first European nation to experience a major outbreak in early 2020, becoming the first country worldwide to introduce a national [lockdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_lockdowns_in_Italy "COVID-19 lockdowns in Italy").[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-319)
triples.statement: Italy was the first European country to have a major outbreak in early 2020 and became the first country in the world to implement a national lockdown.

triples.sentence: By 18 March 2020, more than 250 million people were in [lockdown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stay-at-home_order "Stay-at-home order") in Europe.[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-323)
triples.statement: More than 250 million people in Europe were in lockdown by March 18, 2020.

triples.sentence: Despite [deployment of COVID-19 vaccines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_of_COVID-19_vaccines "Deployment of COVID-19 vaccines"), Europe became the pandemic's epicentre once again in late 2021.[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-324)[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-325)
triples.statement: In late 2021, Europe once again became the pandemic's epicentre, despite the deployment of COVID-19 vaccines.

triples.sentence: The [Italian outbreak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Italy "COVID-19 pandemic in Italy") began on 31 January 2020, when two Chinese tourists tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 in Rome.[[215]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Corriere_20Jan-216)
triples.statement: The Italian outbreak started on January 31, 2020, after two Chinese tourists in Rome tested positive for SARS-CoV-2.

triples.sentence: Sport was suspended completely for at least one month.[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Kv4Ld-328)
triples.statement: All sports were suspended for a minimum of one month.

triples.sentence: On 11 March, Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte closed down nearly all commercial activity except supermarkets and pharmacies.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-To26Y-329)[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ClzT6-330)
triples.statement: On March 11, Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte ordered the closure of almost all commercial activities, excluding supermarkets and pharmacies.

triples.sentence: On 19 April, the first wave ebbed, as 7-day deaths declined to 433.[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-thehill493586-331)
triples.statement: The first wave subsided by April 19, with the 7-day death count falling to 433.

triples.sentence: On 13 October, the Italian government again issued restrictive rules to contain the second wave.[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-KhaW7-332)
triples.statement: To manage the second wave, the Italian government implemented new restrictive rules on October 13.

triples.sentence: On 10 November, Italy surpassed 1 million confirmed infections.[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-8XEwk-333)
triples.statement: Italy's confirmed infections exceeded 1 million on November 10.

triples.sentence: On 23 November, it was reported that the second wave of the virus had led some hospitals to stop accepting patients.[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-334)
triples.statement: It was reported on November 23 that the second wave had caused some hospitals to cease admitting new patients.

triples.sentence: The virus was first confirmed to have spread to Spain on 31 January 2020, when a German tourist tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 on [La Gomera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Gomera "La Gomera") in the Canary Islands.[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SanidadConfirmaEnLaGomera-335)
triples.statement: The first confirmed case of the virus in Spain was on January 31, 2020, involving a German tourist on La Gomera in the Canary Islands.

triples.sentence: Post-hoc genetic analysis has shown that at least 15 strains of the virus had been imported, and [community transmission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_transmission "Community transmission") began by mid-February.[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-genetic_analysis-336)
triples.statement: Genetic analysis later revealed that at least 15 different strains of the virus were imported into Spain, with community transmission starting by mid-February.

triples.sentence: By September 2021, Spain was one of the countries with the highest percentage of its population vaccinated (76% fully vaccinated and 79% with the first dose).[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto2-342)
triples.statement: By September 2021, Spain had one of the highest vaccination rates, with 76% of its population fully vaccinated and 79% having received at least one dose.

triples.sentence: Italy is ranked second at 75%.[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto2-342)
triples.statement: Italy ranked second in vaccination rates at 75%.

triples.sentence: Sweden differed from most other European countries in that it mostly remained open.[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT20200515-343)
triples.statement: Sweden's response differed from most European countries as it largely remained open.

triples.sentence: The Swedish strategy focused on longer-term measures, based on the assumption that after lockdown the virus would resume spreading, with the same result.[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-7ys2k-344)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-I06mN-345)
triples.statement: Sweden's strategy was centered on long-term measures, assuming the virus would spread again after any lockdown, leading to the same outcome.

triples.sentence: By the end of June, Sweden no longer had [excess mortality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Excess_mortality "Excess mortality").[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-HEUrz-346)
triples.statement: By the end of June, Sweden was no longer experiencing excess mortality.

triples.sentence: England's restrictions were shorter-lived than the others.[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-8VnMf-347)
triples.statement: The restrictions in England were of a shorter duration compared to those in the other UK countries.

triples.sentence: The [UK government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom "Government of the United Kingdom") started enforcing social distancing and quarantine measures on 18 March 2020.[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-PkWGD-348)[[348]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Pkx25-349)
triples.statement: The UK government began enforcing social distancing and quarantine measures on March 18, 2020.

triples.sentence: On 20 March, the government ordered all leisure establishments to close,[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dmBNt-352) and promised to prevent unemployment.[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mV2p3-353)
triples.statement: On March 20, the UK government ordered the closure of all leisure establishments and pledged to prevent unemployment.

triples.sentence: Most non-essential businesses were ordered to close.[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc-pm-2403-354)
triples.statement: Most non-essential businesses were ordered to close.

triples.sentence: On 24 April 2020, it was reported that a promising vaccine trial had begun in England; the government pledged more than £50 million towards research.[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vKeXC-355)
triples.statement: It was reported on April 24, 2020, that a promising vaccine trial had started in England, with the government committing over £50 million to research.

triples.sentence: On 2 December 2020, the UK became the first developed country to approve the Pfizer vaccine; 800,000 doses were immediately available for use.[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-357)
triples.statement: On December 2, 2020, the UK was the first developed nation to approve the Pfizer vaccine, making 800,000 doses immediately available.

triples.sentence: In August 2022 it was reported that viral infection cases had declined in the UK.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-358)
triples.statement: In August 2022, reports indicated a decline in viral infection cases in the UK.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in North America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_North_America "COVID-19 pandemic in North America")

The virus arrived in the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") on 13 January 2020.[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-359) Cases were reported in all North American countries after [Saint Kitts and Nevis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Saint_Kitts_and_Nevis "COVID-19 pandemic in Saint Kitts and Nevis") confirmed a case on 25 March, and in all North American territories after [Bonaire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Bonaire "COVID-19 pandemic in Bonaire") confirmed a case on 16 April.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-FirstBonaire_local-360)

[![Image 45](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/USNS_Comfort_New_York_City_2020.jpg/250px-USNS_Comfort_New_York_City_2020.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:USNS_Comfort_New_York_City_2020.jpg)

The hospital ship [USNS _Comfort_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USNS_Comfort "USNS Comfort") arrives in [Manhattan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan "Manhattan") on 30 March 2020

Per _Our World in Data_, 103,436,829[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) confirmed cases have been reported in the United States with 1,228,289[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) deaths, the most of any country, and [the nineteenth-highest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_death_rates_by_country "COVID-19 pandemic death rates by country") per capita worldwide.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-JH_Mortality-361) COVID-19 is the [deadliest pandemic in US history](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_disasters_in_the_United_States_by_death_toll "List of disasters in the United States by death toll");[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-362) it was the third-leading cause of death in the US in 2020, behind heart disease and cancer.[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-363) From 2019 to 2020, US life expectancy dropped by 3 years for Hispanic Americans, 2.9 years for African Americans, and 1.2 years for white Americans.[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Bosman-364) These effects have persisted as US deaths due to COVID-19 in 2021 exceeded those in 2020.[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-365) In the United States, COVID-19 vaccines became available under emergency use in December 2020, beginning the [national vaccination programme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccination_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 vaccination in the United States"). The first COVID-19 vaccine was officially approved by the [Food and Drug Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration "Food and Drug Administration") on 23 August 2021.[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-366) By 18 November 2022, while cases in the U.S. had declined, COVID variants BQ.1/BQ.1.1 had become dominant in the country.[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-367)[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-368)

In March 2020, as cases of community transmission were confirmed across [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Canada "COVID-19 pandemic in Canada"), all of its provinces and territories declared states of emergency. Provinces and territories, to varying degrees, implemented school and daycare closures, prohibitions on gatherings, closures of non-essential businesses and restrictions on entry. Canada severely restricted its border access, barring travellers from all countries with some exceptions.[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-369) Cases surged across Canada, notably in the provinces of [British Columbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_British_Columbia "COVID-19 pandemic in British Columbia"), [Alberta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Alberta "COVID-19 pandemic in Alberta"), [Quebec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Quebec "COVID-19 pandemic in Quebec") and [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Ontario "COVID-19 pandemic in Ontario"), with the formation of the [Atlantic Bubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Bubble "Atlantic Bubble"), a [travel-restricted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_restrictions_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic") area of the country (formed of the four [Atlantic provinces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Canada "Atlantic Canada")).[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-370) Vaccine passports were adopted in all provinces and two of the territories.[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-371)[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-372) Per a report on 11 November 2022, Canadian health authorities saw a surge in influenza, while COVID-19 was expected to rise during winter.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-373)

triples.sentence: The virus arrived in the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") on 13 January 2020.[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-359)
triples.statement: The virus arrived in the United States on 13 January 2020.

triples.sentence: Cases were reported in all North American countries after [Saint Kitts and Nevis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Saint_Kitts_and_Nevis "COVID-19 pandemic in Saint Kitts and Nevis") confirmed a case on 25 March, and in all North American territories after [Bonaire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Bonaire "COVID-19 pandemic in Bonaire") confirmed a case on 16 April.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-FirstBonaire_local-360)
triples.statement: By March 25, all North American countries had reported COVID-19 cases, and by April 16, all North American territories had reported cases.

triples.sentence: Per _Our World in Data_, 103,436,829[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) confirmed cases have been reported in the United States with 1,228,289[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) deaths, the most of any country, and [the nineteenth-highest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_death_rates_by_country "COVID-19 pandemic death rates by country") per capita worldwide.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-JH_Mortality-361)
triples.statement: According to Our World in Data, the United States has reported 103,436,829 confirmed cases and 1,228,289 deaths, the highest total of any country and the nineteenth-highest per capita death rate globally.

triples.sentence: These effects have persisted as US deaths due to COVID-19 in 2021 exceeded those in 2020.[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-365)
triples.statement: The number of US deaths from COVID-19 in 2021 was higher than in 2020.

triples.sentence: The first COVID-19 vaccine was officially approved by the [Food and Drug Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration "Food and Drug Administration") on 23 August 2021.[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-366)
triples.statement: The Food and Drug Administration officially approved the first COVID-19 vaccine on August 23, 2021.

triples.sentence: By 18 November 2022, while cases in the U.S. had declined, COVID variants BQ.1/BQ.1.1 had become dominant in the country.[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-367)[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-368)
triples.statement: By November 18, 2022, the COVID variants BQ.1 and BQ.1.1 had become dominant in the U.S., even as overall cases had declined.

triples.sentence: Cases surged across Canada, notably in the provinces of [British Columbia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_British_Columbia "COVID-19 pandemic in British Columbia"), [Alberta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Alberta "COVID-19 pandemic in Alberta"), [Quebec](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Quebec "COVID-19 pandemic in Quebec") and [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Ontario "COVID-19 pandemic in Ontario"), with the formation of the [Atlantic Bubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Bubble "Atlantic Bubble"), a [travel-restricted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_restrictions_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic") area of the country (formed of the four [Atlantic provinces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atlantic_Canada "Atlantic Canada")).[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-370)
triples.statement: COVID-19 cases surged across Canada, particularly in British Columbia, Alberta, Quebec, and Ontario, leading to the creation of the travel-restricted Atlantic Bubble.

triples.sentence: Per a report on 11 November 2022, Canadian health authorities saw a surge in influenza, while COVID-19 was expected to rise during winter.[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-373)
triples.statement: A report on November 11, 2022, indicated that Canadian health authorities observed a surge in influenza and expected a rise in COVID-19 during the winter.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in South America](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_South_America "COVID-19 pandemic in South America")

[![Image 46](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Fosas_comunes_en_Cochabamba.jpg/250px-Fosas_comunes_en_Cochabamba.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Fosas_comunes_en_Cochabamba.jpg)

Mass graves being prepared for COVID-19 victims in [Cochabamba](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cochabamba "Cochabamba"), Bolivia

The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have reached South America on 26 February 2020, when Brazil confirmed a case in [São Paulo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo "São Paulo").[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-374) By 3 April, all countries and territories in South America had recorded at least one case.[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Stuff/Fairfax-375) On 13 May 2020, it was reported that Latin America and the [Caribbean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean") had reported over 400,000 cases of COVID-19 infection with 23,091 deaths. On 22 May 2020, citing the rapid increase of [infections in Brazil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil"), the WHO declared South America the epicentre of the pandemic.[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-376)[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-377) As of 16 July 2021, South America had recorded 34,359,631 confirmed cases and 1,047,229 deaths from COVID-19. Due to a shortage of testing and medical facilities, it is believed that the outbreak is far larger than the official numbers show.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-378)

The virus was confirmed to have spread to Brazil on 25 February 2020,[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-379) when a man from [São Paulo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%A3o_Paulo "São Paulo") who had travelled to Italy tested positive for the virus.[[379]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-380) The disease had spread to every [federative unit of Brazil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federative_units_of_Brazil "Federative units of Brazil") by 21 March. On 19 June 2020, the country reported its one millionth case and nearly 49,000 reported deaths.[[380]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-381)[[381]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-382) One estimate of [under-reporting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Under-reporting#Disease "Under-reporting") was 22.62% of total reported COVID-19 mortality in 2020.[[382]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-383)[[383]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-384)[[384]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-385) As of 05 December 2025, Brazil, with 37,903,843[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) confirmed cases and 703,536[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Template:COVID-19_data-5) deaths, has the third-highest number of confirmed cases and second-highest death toll from COVID-19 in the world, behind only [those of the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") and [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India").[[385]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-386)

triples.sentence: On 22 May 2020, citing the rapid increase of [infections in Brazil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil"), the WHO declared South America the epicentre of the pandemic.[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-376)[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-377)
triples.statement: On May 22, 2020, the WHO declared South America the epicentre of the pandemic, citing the rapid increase of infections in Brazil.

triples.sentence: Due to a shortage of testing and medical facilities, it is believed that the outbreak is far larger than the official numbers show.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-378)
triples.statement: Due to a shortage of testing and medical facilities, the outbreak is believed to be far larger than official numbers show.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Africa "COVID-19 pandemic in Africa")

[![Image 47](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Air_Forces_Africa_delivers_medical_supplies_to_Ghana_%2849829156488%29.jpg/250px-Air_Forces_Africa_delivers_medical_supplies_to_Ghana_%2849829156488%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Air_Forces_Africa_delivers_medical_supplies_to_Ghana_(49829156488).jpg)

[US Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force") personnel unload a [C-17](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_C-17_Globemaster_III "Boeing C-17 Globemaster III") aircraft carrying medical supplies in [Niamey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Niamey "Niamey"), Niger, in April 2020.

The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have spread to Africa on 14 February 2020, with the first confirmed case announced in [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Egypt "COVID-19 pandemic in Egypt").[[386]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_51509248-387)[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-388) The first confirmed case in [sub-Saharan Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa "Sub-Saharan Africa") was announced in [Nigeria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Nigeria "COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria") at the end of February 2020.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_51671834-389) Within three months, the virus had spread throughout the continent; [Lesotho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Lesotho "COVID-19 pandemic in Lesotho"), the last African sovereign state to have remained free of the virus, reported its first case on 13 May 2020.[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters_idUSKBN22P1R4-390)[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-latimes.com-391) By 26 May, it appeared that most African countries were experiencing community transmission, although testing capacity was limited.[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-theguardian_20200526_africa-392) Most of the identified imported cases arrived from Europe and the United States rather than from China where the virus originated.[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Africa_Braces-393) Many preventive measures [were implemented](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_Africa "National responses to the COVID-19 pandemic in Africa") by different countries in Africa including travel restrictions, flight cancellations, and event cancellations.[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-394) Despite fears, Africa reported lower death rates than other, more economically developed regions.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT_Africa_deaths-395)

In early June 2021, Africa faced a third wave of COVID infections with cases rising in 14 countries.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-theguardian_20210607_third-396) By 4 July the continent recorded more than 251,000 new COVID cases, a 20% increase from the prior week and a 12% increase from the January peak. More than sixteen African countries, including [Malawi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Malawi "COVID-19 pandemic in Malawi") and [Senegal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Senegal "COVID-19 pandemic in Senegal"), recorded an uptick in new cases.[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Mendez-397) The WHO labelled it Africa's 'Worst Pandemic Week Ever'.[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-398) In October 2022, WHO reported that most countries on the African continent will miss the goal of 70 per cent vaccination by the end of 2022.[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-399)

triples.sentence: The first confirmed case in [sub-Saharan Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa "Sub-Saharan Africa") was announced in [Nigeria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Nigeria "COVID-19 pandemic in Nigeria") at the end of February 2020.[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bbc_51671834-389)
triples.statement: The first confirmed COVID-19 case in sub-Saharan Africa was announced in Nigeria at the end of February 2020.

triples.sentence: Within three months, the virus had spread throughout the continent; [Lesotho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Lesotho "COVID-19 pandemic in Lesotho"), the last African sovereign state to have remained free of the virus, reported its first case on 13 May 2020.[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters_idUSKBN22P1R4-390)[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-latimes.com-391)
triples.statement: Within three months, the virus spread across the continent, with Lesotho, the last African sovereign state to be virus-free, reporting its first case on May 13, 2020.

triples.statement: By May 26, it seemed most African countries were experiencing community transmission, though testing capacity was limited.

triples.statement: Many African countries implemented preventive measures, including travel restrictions, flight cancellations, and event cancellations.

triples.sentence: Despite fears, Africa reported lower death rates than other, more economically developed regions.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT_Africa_deaths-395)
triples.statement: Africa reported lower death rates from COVID-19 than other, more economically developed regions.

triples.sentence: In early June 2021, Africa faced a third wave of COVID infections with cases rising in 14 countries.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-theguardian_20210607_third-396)
triples.statement: In early June 2021, Africa experienced a third wave of COVID-19 infections, with cases increasing in 14 countries.

triples.statement: More than sixteen African countries, including Malawi and Senegal, recorded an increase in new cases.

section_body:
Main article: [COVID-19 pandemic in Oceania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Oceania "COVID-19 pandemic in Oceania")

[![Image 48](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Empty_shelves_at_Coles_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brisbane%2C_Australia.jpg/250px-Empty_shelves_at_Coles_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brisbane%2C_Australia.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Empty_shelves_at_Coles_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brisbane,_Australia.jpg)

Empty shelves at a [Coles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coles_Supermarkets "Coles Supermarkets") grocery store in [Brisbane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane"), Australia, in April 2020

The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have reached Oceania on 25 January 2020, with the first confirmed case reported in [Melbourne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne"), [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Australia "COVID-19 pandemic in Australia").[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AustraliaCase1-400)[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Brisbane2021-401) It has since spread elsewhere in the region.[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Dashboard-402)[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Brisbane2021-401)[Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Australia "COVID-19 pandemic in Australia") and [New Zealand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_New_Zealand "COVID-19 pandemic in New Zealand") were praised for their handling of the pandemic in comparison to other Western nations, with New Zealand and each state in Australia wiping out all community transmission of the virus several times even after re-introduction into the community.[[402]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters-oz-10days-403)[[403]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-bloomberg-oz-tassie-price-404)[[404]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-405)

As a result of the high transmissibility of the Delta variant, however, by August 2021, the Australian states of [New South Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_South_Wales "New South Wales") and [Victoria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_(Australia) "Victoria (Australia)") had conceded defeat in their eradication efforts.[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-406) In early October 2021, New Zealand also abandoned its elimination strategy.[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-The_Guardian_NZ_abandons_elimination-407) In November and December, following vaccination efforts, the remaining states of Australia, excluding Western Australia, voluntarily gave up [COVID-Zero](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-COVID "Zero-COVID") to open up state and international borders.[[407]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-408)[[408]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-409)[[409]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-410) The open borders allowed the Omicron variant of COVID-19 to enter quickly, and cases subsequently exceeded 120,000 a day.[[410]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-411) By early March 2022, with cases exceeding 1,000 a day, Western Australia conceded defeat in its eradication strategy and opened its borders.[[411]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-412) Despite record cases, Australian jurisdictions slowly removed restrictions such as close contact isolation, mask wearing, and density limits by April 2022.[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-413)

On 9 September 2022, restrictions were significantly relaxed. The aircraft mask mandate was scrapped nationwide, and daily reporting transitioned to weekly reporting.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-414)[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-415)[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-416) On 14 September, COVID-19 disaster payment for isolating persons was extended for mandatory isolation.[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-417) By 22 September, all states had ended mask mandates on public transport, including in Victoria, where the mandate had lasted for approximately 800 days.[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-418) On 30 September 2022, all Australian leaders declared the emergency response finished and announced the end of isolation requirements. These changes were due in part to high levels of 'hybrid immunity' and low case numbers.[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-419)

triples.sentence: The COVID-19 pandemic was confirmed to have reached Oceania on 25 January 2020, with the first confirmed case reported in [Melbourne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne"), [Australia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Australia "COVID-19 pandemic in Australia").[[399]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AustraliaCase1-400)[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Brisbane2021-401)
triples.statement: The COVID-19 pandemic reached Oceania on January 25, 2020, with the first confirmed case reported in Melbourne, Australia.

triples.sentence: It has since spread elsewhere in the region.[[401]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-WHO_Dashboard-402)[[400]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Brisbane2021-401)
triples.statement: The virus subsequently spread to other parts of the region.

triples.sentence: As a result of the high transmissibility of the Delta variant, however, by August 2021, the Australian states of [New South Wales](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_South_Wales "New South Wales") and [Victoria](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_(Australia) "Victoria (Australia)") had conceded defeat in their eradication efforts.[[405]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-406)
triples.statement: Due to the high transmissibility of the Delta variant, the Australian states of New South Wales and Victoria abandoned their eradication efforts by August 2021.

triples.sentence: In early October 2021, New Zealand also abandoned its elimination strategy.[[406]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-The_Guardian_NZ_abandons_elimination-407)
triples.statement: In early October 2021, New Zealand also gave up its elimination strategy.
