triples.statement: By early March 2022, as daily cases surpassed 1,000, Western Australia abandoned its eradication strategy and opened its borders.

triples.sentence: Despite record cases, Australian jurisdictions slowly removed restrictions such as close contact isolation, mask wearing, and density limits by April 2022.[[412]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-413)
triples.statement: By April 2022, despite record case numbers, Australian jurisdictions gradually removed restrictions including close contact isolation, mask wearing, and density limits.

triples.sentence: The aircraft mask mandate was scrapped nationwide, and daily reporting transitioned to weekly reporting.[[413]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-414)[[414]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-415)[[415]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-416)
triples.statement: The nationwide aircraft mask mandate was removed, and case reporting shifted from daily to weekly.

triples.sentence: On 14 September, COVID-19 disaster payment for isolating persons was extended for mandatory isolation.[[416]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-417)
triples.statement: On September 14, the COVID-19 disaster payment for individuals in mandatory isolation was extended.

triples.sentence: By 22 September, all states had ended mask mandates on public transport, including in Victoria, where the mandate had lasted for approximately 800 days.[[417]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-418)
triples.statement: By September 22, all Australian states had ended mask mandates on public transport; Victoria's mandate had been in place for about 800 days.

triples.sentence: On 30 September 2022, all Australian leaders declared the emergency response finished and announced the end of isolation requirements.[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-419)
triples.statement: On September 30, 2022, Australian leaders declared the end of the emergency response and announced the termination of isolation requirements.

triples.sentence: These changes were due in part to high levels of 'hybrid immunity' and low case numbers.[[418]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-419)
triples.statement: These changes were attributed in part to high levels of 'hybrid immunity' and low case numbers.

section_body:
Main article: [United Nations response to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_response_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "United Nations response to the COVID-19 pandemic")

The [United Nations Conference on Trade and Development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_Trade_and_Development "United Nations Conference on Trade and Development") (UNSC) was criticised for its slow response, especially regarding the UN's [global ceasefire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_ceasefire "Global ceasefire"), which aimed to open up humanitarian access to conflict zones.[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:22-425)[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Krm4a-426) The United Nations Security Council was criticised due to the inadequate manner in which it dealt with the COVID-19 pandemic, namely the poor ability to create international collaboration during this crisis.[[426]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-427)[[427]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-428)

On 23 March 2020, United Nations Secretary-General [António Manuel de Oliveira Guterres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Guterres "António Guterres") appealed for a global [ceasefire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ceasefire "Ceasefire");[[428]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-tFb4N-429)[[429]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-lzoeV-430) 172 UN member states and observers signed a non-binding supporting statement in June,[[430]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AGhvz-431) and the [UN Security Council](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UN_Security_Council "UN Security Council") passed a [resolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_2532 "United Nations Security Council Resolution 2532") supporting it in July.[[431]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-9rN79-432)[[432]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-nJTuX-433)

On 29 September 2020, Guterres urged the [International Monetary Fund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund") to help certain countries via debt relief and also call for countries to increase contributions to develop vaccines.[[433]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-434)

triples.sentence: The [United Nations Conference on Trade and Development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_Trade_and_Development "United Nations Conference on Trade and Development") (UNSC) was criticised for its slow response, especially regarding the UN's [global ceasefire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_ceasefire "Global ceasefire"), which aimed to open up humanitarian access to conflict zones.[[424]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-:22-425)[[425]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Krm4a-426)
triples.statement: The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNSC) was criticized for its slow response, particularly regarding the UN's global ceasefire aimed at providing humanitarian access to conflict zones.

section_body:
Further information: [Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic") and [International aid related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_aid_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "International aid related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 50: Workers unloading boxes of medical supplies at Villamor Air Base.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/China_COVID19_test_kit_PH_donation_8.jpg/250px-China_COVID19_test_kit_PH_donation_8.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:China_COVID19_test_kit_PH_donation_8.jpg)

Donated medical supplies received in the Philippines

The pandemic shook the world's economy, with especially severe economic damage in the United States, Europe and Latin America.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-437)[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Effect_of_COVID-19_on_food_security-438) A consensus report by American intelligence agencies in April 2021 concluded, "Efforts to contain and manage the virus have reinforced nationalist trends globally, as some states turned inward to protect their citizens and sometimes cast blame on marginalised groups". COVID-19 inflamed partisanship and polarisation around the world as bitter arguments exploded over how to respond. International trade was disrupted amid the formation of no-entry enclaves.[[438]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-439)

triples.sentence: The pandemic shook the world's economy, with especially severe economic damage in the United States, Europe and Latin America.[[436]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-437)[[437]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Effect_of_COVID-19_on_food_security-438)
triples.statement: The pandemic caused a global economic shock, with particularly severe damage in the United States, Europe, and Latin America.

section_body:
Main article: [Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travel_restrictions_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

The pandemic led many countries and regions to impose quarantines, entry bans, or other restrictions, either for citizens, recent travellers to affected areas,[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200326nytimes-440) or for all travellers.[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-441)[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-442) Travel collapsed worldwide, damaging the travel sector. The effectiveness of travel restrictions was questioned as the virus spread across the world.[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200224nationalgeographic-443) One study found that travel restrictions only modestly affected the initial spread, unless combined with other [infection prevention and control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infection_prevention_and_control "Infection prevention and control") measures.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-DJYtB-444)[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-445) Researchers concluded that "travel restrictions are most useful in the early and late phase of an epidemic" and "restrictions of travel from Wuhan unfortunately came too late".[[445]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-283GD-446) The European Union rejected the idea of suspending the [Schengen free travel zone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schengen_Agreement "Schengen Agreement").[[446]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dw52497811-447)[[447]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200313euractiv-448)

triples.sentence: The pandemic led many countries and regions to impose quarantines, entry bans, or other restrictions, either for citizens, recent travellers to affected areas,[[439]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200326nytimes-440) or for all travellers.[[440]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-441)[[441]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-442)
triples.statement: During the pandemic, many countries and regions imposed restrictions such as quarantines and entry bans for citizens, recent travelers to affected areas, or all travelers.

triples.sentence: The effectiveness of travel restrictions was questioned as the virus spread across the world.[[442]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200224nationalgeographic-443)
triples.statement: As the virus spread globally, the effectiveness of travel restrictions was questioned.

triples.sentence: One study found that travel restrictions only modestly affected the initial spread, unless combined with other [infection prevention and control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infection_prevention_and_control "Infection prevention and control") measures.[[443]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-DJYtB-444)[[444]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-445)
triples.statement: A study found that travel restrictions had only a modest effect on the initial spread of the virus unless they were combined with other infection prevention and control measures.

section_body:
Main article: [Evacuations related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evacuations_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Evacuations related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 51](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Ukraine_evacuates_Ukrainian_and_foreign_citizens_from_Wuhan_16.jpg/250px-Ukraine_evacuates_Ukrainian_and_foreign_citizens_from_Wuhan_16.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ukraine_evacuates_Ukrainian_and_foreign_citizens_from_Wuhan_16.jpg)

Ukraine evacuates Ukrainian citizens from [Wuhan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wuhan "Wuhan"), China.

Several countries repatriated their citizens and diplomatic staff from Wuhan and surrounding areas, primarily through [charter flights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_charter "Air charter"). Canada, the United States, Japan, India, Sri Lanka, Australia, France, Argentina, Germany and Thailand were among the first to do so.[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-169-449) Brazil and New Zealand evacuated their own nationals and others.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-171-450)[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-6l9jG-451) On 14 March, South Africa repatriated 112 South Africans who tested negative, while four who showed symptoms were left behind.[[451]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto3-452) Pakistan declined to evacuate its citizens.[[452]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200131dialoguepakistan-453)

On 15 February, the US announced it would evacuate Americans aboard the _[Diamond Princess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamond\_Princess\_outbreak "Diamond Princess outbreak")_ cruise ship,[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-174-454) and on 21 February, Canada evacuated 129 Canadians from the ship.[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-175-455) In early March, the Indian government began repatriating its citizens from Iran.[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-czjOG-456)[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-indiatimes74647353-457) On 20 March, the United States began to withdraw some troops from Iraq.[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-USWithdraw-458)

triples.sentence: Canada, the United States, Japan, India, Sri Lanka, Australia, France, Argentina, Germany and Thailand were among the first to do so.[[448]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-169-449)
triples.statement: Canada, the United States, Japan, India, Sri Lanka, Australia, France, Argentina, Germany and Thailand were among the first countries to repatriate their citizens.

triples.sentence: Brazil and New Zealand evacuated their own nationals and others.[[449]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-171-450)[[450]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-6l9jG-451)
triples.statement: Brazil and New Zealand evacuated their own nationals and citizens of other countries.

triples.sentence: On 15 February, the US announced it would evacuate Americans aboard the _[Diamond Princess](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diamond_Princess_outbreak "Diamond Princess outbreak")_ cruise ship,[[453]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-174-454) and on 21 February, Canada evacuated 129 Canadians from the ship.[[454]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-175-455)
triples.statement: The US announced on February 15 that it would evacuate Americans from the Diamond Princess cruise ship, and on February 21, Canada evacuated 129 of its citizens from the vessel.

triples.sentence: In early March, the Indian government began repatriating its citizens from Iran.[[455]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-czjOG-456)[[456]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-indiatimes74647353-457)
triples.statement: In early March, the Indian government started repatriating its citizens from Iran.

triples.sentence: On 20 March, the United States began to withdraw some troops from Iraq.[[457]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-USWithdraw-458)
triples.statement: On March 20, the United States began to withdraw some troops from Iraq.

section_body:
Main article: [Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic")

See also: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on aviation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_aviation "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on aviation"), [on science and technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_science_and_technology "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on science and technology"), [on financial markets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_market_impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Financial market impact of the COVID-19 pandemic"), [2020 stock market crash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_stock_market_crash "2020 stock market crash"), and [COVID-19 recession](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_recession "COVID-19 recession")

[![Image 52](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Stock-indices-2020crash%2Brecovery.svg/330px-Stock-indices-2020crash%2Brecovery.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Stock-indices-2020crash%2Brecovery.svg)

A [stock index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stock_index "Stock index") chart shows the [2020 stock market crash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_stock_market_crash "2020 stock market crash").

The pandemic and responses to it damaged the global economy. On 27 February 2020, worries about the outbreak crushed US stock indexes, which posted their sharpest falls since 2008.[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-U7teI-459)

Tourism collapsed due to travel restrictions, closing of public places including travel attractions, and advice of governments against travel. Airlines cancelled flights, while British regional airline [Flybe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flybe_(1979%E2%80%932020) "Flybe (1979–2020)") collapsed.[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-z2VrM-460) The cruise line industry was hard hit,[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-smh20200227-461) and train stations and ferry ports closed.[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wnn7L-462) International mail stopped or was delayed.[[462]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wsj1158868721-463)

The retail sector faced reductions in store hours or closures.[[463]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-464) Retailers in Europe and Latin America faced traffic declines of 40 per cent. North America and Middle East retailers saw a 50–60 per cent drop.[[464]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200402aislelabs-465) Shopping centres faced a 33–43 per cent drop in foot traffic in March compared to February. Mall operators around the world coped by increasing sanitation, installing thermal scanners to check the temperature of shoppers, and cancelling events.[[465]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-J6Y6Z-466)

Hundreds of millions of jobs were lost,[[466]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-aljazeera2004271718-467)[[467]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200506csmonitor-468) including more than 40 million jobs in the US.[[468]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200528WaPo-469) According to a report by [Yelp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yelp "Yelp"), about 60% of US businesses that closed will stay shut permanently.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vLHxV-470) The [International Labour Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Labour_Organization "International Labour Organization") (ILO) reported that the income generated in the first nine months of 2020 from work across the world dropped by 10.7%, or $3.5 trillion.[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-rd8bm-471)

triples.sentence: On 27 February 2020, worries about the outbreak crushed US stock indexes, which posted their sharpest falls since 2008.[[458]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-U7teI-459)
triples.statement: On February 27, 2020, concerns about the outbreak led to US stock indexes posting their sharpest declines since 2008.

triples.sentence: Airlines cancelled flights, while British regional airline [Flybe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flybe_(1979%E2%80%932020) "Flybe (1979–2020)") collapsed.[[459]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-z2VrM-460)
triples.statement: Airlines cancelled flights, and the British regional airline Flybe collapsed.

triples.sentence: The cruise line industry was hard hit,[[460]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-smh20200227-461) and train stations and ferry ports closed.[[461]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-wnn7L-462)
triples.statement: The cruise line industry was severely impacted, and train stations and ferry ports were closed.

triples.sentence: Hundreds of millions of jobs were lost,[[466]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-aljazeera2004271718-467)[[467]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200506csmonitor-468) including more than 40 million jobs in the US.[[468]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200528WaPo-469)
triples.statement: Hundreds of millions of jobs were lost, including over 40 million in the US.

triples.sentence: According to a report by [Yelp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yelp "Yelp"), about 60% of US businesses that closed will stay shut permanently.[[469]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vLHxV-470)
triples.statement: A report by Yelp indicated that about 60% of US businesses that closed will remain permanently shut.

triples.sentence: The [International Labour Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Labour_Organization "International Labour Organization") (ILO) reported that the income generated in the first nine months of 2020 from work across the world dropped by 10.7%, or $3.5 trillion.[[470]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-rd8bm-471)
triples.statement: The International Labour Organization (ILO) reported that global income from work dropped by 10.7%, or $3.5 trillion, in the first nine months of 2020.

section_body:
Main article: [Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortages_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Shortages related to the COVID-19 pandemic")

[![Image 53](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ntuc_super_store%2C_Singapore_%2849505410793%29.jpg/250px-Ntuc_super_store%2C_Singapore_%2849505410793%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ntuc_super_store,_Singapore_(49505410793).jpg)

COVID-19 fears led to panic buying of essentials across the world, including toilet paper, instant noodles, bread, rice, vegetables, disinfectant, and rubbing alcohol (picture taken in February 2020).

Pandemic fears led to [panic buying](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panic_buying "Panic buying"), emptying groceries of essentials such as food, toilet paper, and bottled water. Panic buying stemmed from perceived threat, perceived scarcity, fear of the unknown, coping behaviour and social psychological factors (e.g. [social influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence "Social influence") and trust).[[471]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cSvA4-472)

Supply [shortages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortage "Shortage") were due to disruption to factory and logistic operations; shortages were worsened by [supply chain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain "Supply chain") disruptions from factory and port shutdowns, and labour shortages.[[472]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-XvcU9-473)

Shortages continued as managers underestimated the speed of economic recovery after the initial economic crash. The technology industry, in particular, warned of delays from underestimates of [semiconductor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor") demand for vehicles and other products.[[473]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-263-474)

According to WHO Secretary-General Tedros Ghebreyesus, demand for [personal protective equipment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_protective_equipment "Personal protective equipment") (PPE) rose one hundredfold, pushing prices up twentyfold.[[474]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-275-475)[[475]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AutoDW-276-476) PPE stocks were exhausted everywhere.[[476]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Mycfo-477)[[477]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-478)[[478]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-479)

In September 2021, the [World Bank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank "World Bank") reported that food prices remained generally stable and the supply outlook remained positive. However, the poorest countries witnessed a sharp increase in food prices, reaching the highest level since the pandemic began.[[479]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-480)[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto4-481) The Agricultural Commodity Price Index stabilised in the third quarter but remained 17% higher than in January 2021.[[481]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-482)[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto4-481)

By contrast, petroleum products were in surplus at the beginning of the pandemic, as demand for gasoline and other products collapsed due to reduced commuting and other trips.[[482]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BBC,_US_oil_prices,_21_April_2020-483) The [2021 global energy crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_global_energy_crisis "2021 global energy crisis") was driven by a global surge in demand as the world economy recovered. Energy demand was particularly strong in Asia.[[483]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-484)[[484]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-485)

triples.sentence: Panic buying stemmed from perceived threat, perceived scarcity, fear of the unknown, coping behaviour and social psychological factors (e.g. [social influence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence "Social influence") and trust).[[471]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-cSvA4-472)
triples.statement: Panic buying was caused by perceived threats, scarcity, fear of the unknown, coping behaviors, and social psychological factors like social influence and trust.

triples.sentence: Supply [shortages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortage "Shortage") were due to disruption to factory and logistic operations; shortages were worsened by [supply chain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_chain "Supply chain") disruptions from factory and port shutdowns, and labour shortages.[[472]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-XvcU9-473)
triples.statement: Supply shortages were caused by disruptions to factory and logistic operations and were made worse by supply chain issues such as factory and port shutdowns, along with labor shortages.

triples.sentence: However, the poorest countries witnessed a sharp increase in food prices, reaching the highest level since the pandemic began.[[479]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-480)[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto4-481)
triples.statement: The poorest countries, however, saw a sharp rise in food prices, which reached their highest point since the start of the pandemic.

triples.sentence: The Agricultural Commodity Price Index stabilised in the third quarter but remained 17% higher than in January 2021.[[481]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-482)[[480]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-auto4-481)
triples.statement: The Agricultural Commodity Price Index stabilized in the third quarter but was still 17% higher than in January 2021.

triples.sentence: By contrast, petroleum products were in surplus at the beginning of the pandemic, as demand for gasoline and other products collapsed due to reduced commuting and other trips.[[482]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BBC,_US_oil_prices,_21_April_2020-483)
triples.statement: In contrast, there was a surplus of petroleum products early in the pandemic because demand for gasoline and other products fell due to decreased travel.

triples.sentence: Energy demand was particularly strong in Asia.[[483]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-484)[[484]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-485)
triples.statement: Demand for energy was especially high in Asia.

section_body:
Main article: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the arts and cultural heritage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_the_arts_and_cultural_heritage "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the arts and cultural heritage")

The performing arts and [cultural heritage sectors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_heritage_sector "Cultural heritage sector") were profoundly affected by the pandemic. Both organisations' and individuals' operations have been impacted globally. By March 2020, across the world and to varying degrees, museums, libraries, performance venues, and other cultural institutions had been indefinitely closed with their exhibitions, events and performances cancelled or postponed.[[485]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-v5Qlx-486) A 2021 [UNESCO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") report estimated ten million job losses worldwide in the culture and creative industries.[[486]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Ottone-487)[[487]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-488) Some services continued through digital platforms,[[488]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ZljIY-489)[[489]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Burke2020-490)[[490]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SxIEK-491) such as live streaming concerts[[491]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-SZ5Mc-492) or web-based arts festivals.[[492]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-mYlLn-493)

triples.sentence: By March 2020, across the world and to varying degrees, museums, libraries, performance venues, and other cultural institutions had been indefinitely closed with their exhibitions, events and performances cancelled or postponed.[[485]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-v5Qlx-486)
triples.statement: By March 2020, cultural institutions worldwide, including museums, libraries, and performance venues, had closed indefinitely, with events and performances cancelled or postponed.

section_body:
Main article: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on politics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_politics "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on politics")

See also: [Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on international relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_international_relations "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on international relations")

The pandemic affected political systems, causing suspensions of legislative activities,[[493]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200313nationalpost-494) isolations or deaths of politicians,[[494]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200318foreignpolicy-495) and rescheduled elections.[[495]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200427nytimes-496) Although they developed broad support among epidemiologists, NPIs (non-pharmaceutical interventions) were controversial in many countries. Intellectual opposition came primarily from other fields, along with heterodox epidemiologists.[[496]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-74OHE-497)

triples.sentence: The pandemic affected political systems, causing suspensions of legislative activities,[[493]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200313nationalpost-494) isolations or deaths of politicians,[[494]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200318foreignpolicy-495) and rescheduled elections.[[495]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200427nytimes-496)
triples.statement: The pandemic impacted political systems, leading to the suspension of legislative activities, the isolation or death of politicians, and the rescheduling of elections.

section_body:
The pandemic (and the [response of Brazilian politicians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Responses "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil") to it) led to widespread panic, confusion, and pessimism in Brazil.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498) When questioned regarding record deaths in the country in April 2020, Brazilian president [Jair Bolsonaro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jair_Bolsonaro "Jair Bolsonaro") said "So what? I'm sorry. What do you want me to do about it?"[[498]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Conde_2020-499) Bolsonaro disregarded WHO-recommended mitigation techniques and instead [downplayed the risks of the virus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Comments_by_Bolsonaro "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil"), promoted increased economic activity, spread [misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Presidential_responses "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil") about the efficacy of masks, vaccines and public health measures, and distributed unproven treatments including [hydroxychloroquine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chloroquine_and_hydroxychloroquine_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine during the COVID-19 pandemic") and [ivermectin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivermectin_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Ivermectin during the COVID-19 pandemic").[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498) A series of [federal health ministers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Ministers_of_Health_of_Brazil "List of Ministers of Health of Brazil") resigned or were dismissed after they refused to implement Bolsonaro's policies.[[499]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Londono2020-500)

Disagreements between federal and state governments led to a chaotic and delayed response to the rapid spread of the virus,[[500]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Dantas2020-501) exacerbated by preexisting social and economic disparities in the country.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498)[[501]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-CarnutMendesGuerra2020-502) Employment, investment and valuation of the [Brazilian real](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazilian_real "Brazilian real") plummeted to record lows.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498)[[502]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ReutersBrazil2020-503) Brazil was also heavily affected by the Delta and Omicron variants.[[503]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AlcantaraNogueiraShuabTosta2022-504) At the height of the outbreak in the spring of 2021, 3,000+ Brazilians were dying per day.[[504]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BBCBrazilMarch2021-505)[[505]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NPRBrazilApril2021-506) Bolsonaro's loss to [Lula da Silva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lula_da_Silva "Lula da Silva") in the [2022 presidential election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Brazilian_general_election "2022 Brazilian general election") is widely credited to the former's [mishandling of the pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presidency_of_Jair_Bolsonaro#Response_to_COVID-19_pandemic "Presidency of Jair Bolsonaro").[[506]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-ChomskyPolychroniou2023-507)[[507]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-EconomistBolsonaroLoss2022-508)[[508]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Milhorance2022October-509)

triples.sentence: The pandemic (and the [response of Brazilian politicians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Responses "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil") to it) led to widespread panic, confusion, and pessimism in Brazil.[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498)
triples.statement: The COVID-19 pandemic and the response to it by Brazilian politicians resulted in widespread panic, confusion, and pessimism in Brazil.

triples.sentence: I'm sorry. What do you want me to do about it?"[[498]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Conde_2020-499) Bolsonaro disregarded WHO-recommended mitigation techniques and instead [downplayed the risks of the virus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Comments_by_Bolsonaro "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil"), promoted increased economic activity, spread [misinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Brazil#Presidential_responses "COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil") about the efficacy of masks, vaccines and public health measures, and distributed unproven treatments including [hydroxychloroquine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chloroquine_and_hydroxychloroquine_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine during the COVID-19 pandemic") and [ivermectin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ivermectin_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Ivermectin during the COVID-19 pandemic").[[497]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BenderdaSilvaBaum2022-498)
triples.statement: President Bolsonaro disregarded WHO-recommended mitigation techniques, downplayed the virus's risks, promoted economic activity, spread misinformation about public health measures, and distributed unproven treatments like hydroxychloroquine and ivermectin.

triples.sentence: A series of [federal health ministers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Ministers_of_Health_of_Brazil "List of Ministers of Health of Brazil") resigned or were dismissed after they refused to implement Bolsonaro's policies.[[499]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Londono2020-500)
triples.statement: A number of federal health ministers resigned or were dismissed after refusing to implement President Bolsonaro's policies.

triples.sentence: Brazil was also heavily affected by the Delta and Omicron variants.[[503]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AlcantaraNogueiraShuabTosta2022-504)
triples.statement: Brazil was heavily affected by the Delta and Omicron variants.

triples.sentence: At the height of the outbreak in the spring of 2021, 3,000+ Brazilians were dying per day.[[504]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-BBCBrazilMarch2021-505)[[505]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NPRBrazilApril2021-506)
triples.statement: At the peak of the outbreak in spring 2021, more than 3,000 Brazilians were dying each day.

section_body:
Further information: [China–United States relations §COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93United_States_relations#COVID-19 "China–United States relations")

Multiple provincial-level administrators of the [Chinese Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party") (CCP) were dismissed over their handling of quarantine measures. Some commentators claimed this move was intended to protect CCP General Secretary [Xi Jinping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xi_Jinping "Xi Jinping").[[509]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vLpPa-510) The [US intelligence community](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_intelligence_community "US intelligence community") claimed that China intentionally under-reported its COVID-19 caseload.[[510]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200402nytimes-511) The Chinese government maintained that it acted swiftly and transparently.[[511]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-hMc3w-512)[[512]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-513) Journalists and activists in China who reported on the pandemic were detained by authorities,[[513]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-514)[[514]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-515) including [Zhang Zhan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zhang_Zhan "Zhang Zhan"), who was arrested and tortured.[[515]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-516)[[516]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-517)

triples.sentence: Some commentators claimed this move was intended to protect CCP General Secretary [Xi Jinping](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xi_Jinping "Xi Jinping").[[509]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-vLpPa-510)
triples.statement: Some commentators claimed the dismissal of provincial administrators was intended to protect CCP General Secretary Xi Jinping.

triples.sentence: The [US intelligence community](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_intelligence_community "US intelligence community") claimed that China intentionally under-reported its COVID-19 caseload.[[510]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200402nytimes-511)
triples.statement: The US intelligence community claimed that China intentionally under-reported its number of COVID-19 cases.

section_body:
[![Image 54](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Palazzo_Margherita_lit_in_Italian_flag_to_show_solidarity_under_COVID-19_pandemic.jpg/250px-Palazzo_Margherita_lit_in_Italian_flag_to_show_solidarity_under_COVID-19_pandemic.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Palazzo_Margherita_lit_in_Italian_flag_to_show_solidarity_under_COVID-19_pandemic.jpg)

Palazzo Margherita lit in Italian flag to show solidarity during the COVID-19 pandemic on 26 March 2020

In early March 2020, the Italian government criticised the EU's lack of solidarity with Italy.[[517]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-518)[[518]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-519)[[519]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-politico-corona-520) On 22 March 2020, after a phone call with Italian Prime Minister [Giuseppe Conte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giuseppe_Conte "Giuseppe Conte"), Russian president [Vladimir Putin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin") ordered the [Russian army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces "Russian Armed Forces") to send military medics, disinfection vehicles, and other medical equipment to Italy.[[520]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters219081-521)[[521]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200328insideover-522) In early April, Norway and EU states like Romania and Austria started to offer help by sending medical personnel and disinfectant,[[522]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-eumedicalteams-523) and [European Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission") president [Ursula von der Leyen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ursula_von_der_Leyen "Ursula von der Leyen") offered an official apology to the country.[[523]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-euapology-524)

triples.sentence: In early March 2020, the Italian government criticised the EU's lack of solidarity with Italy.[[517]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-518)[[518]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-519)[[519]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-politico-corona-520)
triples.statement: In early March 2020, the Italian government criticized the EU for a lack of solidarity with Italy.

triples.sentence: On 22 March 2020, after a phone call with Italian Prime Minister [Giuseppe Conte](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giuseppe_Conte "Giuseppe Conte"), Russian president [Vladimir Putin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin") ordered the [Russian army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces "Russian Armed Forces") to send military medics, disinfection vehicles, and other medical equipment to Italy.[[520]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-reuters219081-521)[[521]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200328insideover-522)
triples.statement: On 22 March 2020, after a phone call with Italian Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte, Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered the Russian army to send military medics, disinfection vehicles, and other medical equipment to Italy.

triples.sentence: In early April, Norway and EU states like Romania and Austria started to offer help by sending medical personnel and disinfectant,[[522]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-eumedicalteams-523) and [European Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission") president [Ursula von der Leyen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ursula_von_der_Leyen "Ursula von der Leyen") offered an official apology to the country.[[523]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-euapology-524)
triples.statement: In early April, Norway and EU member states such as Romania and Austria began to provide aid by sending medical staff and disinfectant, and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen officially apologized to Italy.

section_body:
[![Image 55](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Open_Ohio_Rally_IMG_0910_%2849799974031%29.jpg/250px-Open_Ohio_Rally_IMG_0910_%2849799974031%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Open_Ohio_Rally_IMG_0910_(49799974031).jpg)

Anti-lockdown [protesters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protests_over_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Protests over responses to the COVID-19 pandemic") rallied at [Ohio Statehouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_Statehouse "Ohio Statehouse") 20 April 2020.[[524]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Columbus_Dispatch-525)

Beginning in mid-April 2020, protestors objected to government-imposed business closures and restrictions on personal movement and assembly.[[525]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-5YqAF-526) Simultaneously, [essential workers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Essential_workers "Essential workers") protested unsafe conditions and low wages by participating in a brief [general strike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_strike "General strike").[[526]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-c114M-527) Some political analysts claimed that the pandemic contributed to US president [Donald Trump](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump")'s [2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_presidential_election "2020 United States presidential election") defeat.[[527]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-TrumpChances-528)[[528]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-AtlanticChances-529)

The [COVID-19 pandemic in the United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_States "COVID-19 pandemic in the United States") prompted calls for the United States to adopt social policies common in other wealthy countries, including [universal health care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_health_care "Universal health care"), [universal child care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_child_care "Universal child care"), [paid sick leave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paid_sick_leave "Paid sick leave"), and higher levels of funding for public health.[[529]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-NYT_Calls-530)[[530]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Hill5-531)[[531]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Ddn2P-532) The [Kaiser Family Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaiser_Family_Foundation "Kaiser Family Foundation") estimated that preventable hospitalisations of unvaccinated Americans in the second half of 2021 cost US$13.8 billion.[[532]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Amin-533)

There were also protest in regards to vaccine mandates in the United States.[[533]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-534) In January 2022, the US Supreme Court struck down an OSHA rule that mandated vaccination or a testing regimen for all companies with greater than 100 employees.[[534]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-535)[[535]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-536)

Anti-lockdown [protesters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protests_over_responses_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic "Protests over responses to the COVID-19 pandemic") rallied at [Ohio Statehouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_Statehouse "Ohio Statehouse") 20 April 2020.[[524]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Columbus_Dispatch-525)

triples.statement: Starting in mid-April 2020, protestors objected to government-imposed closures of businesses and restrictions on personal movement and assembly.

triples.sentence: The [Kaiser Family Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaiser_Family_Foundation "Kaiser Family Foundation") estimated that preventable hospitalisations of unvaccinated Americans in the second half of 2021 cost US$13.8 billion.[[532]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-Amin-533)
triples.statement: The Kaiser Family Foundation estimated that preventable hospitalizations of unvaccinated Americans cost US$13.8 billion in the second half of 2021.

triples.statement: Protests also occurred in the United States regarding vaccine mandates.

triples.sentence: In January 2022, the US Supreme Court struck down an OSHA rule that mandated vaccination or a testing regimen for all companies with greater than 100 employees.[[534]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-535)[[535]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-536)
triples.statement: In January 2022, the US Supreme Court invalidated an OSHA rule that required vaccination or testing for all companies with more than 100 employees.

section_body:
The number of journalists imprisoned or detained increased worldwide; some detentions were related to the pandemic.[[536]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-537)[[537]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-538) The planned [NATO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO "NATO") "[Defender 2020](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_NATO_exercises#2020 "List of NATO exercises")" military exercise in Germany, [Poland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poland "Poland") and the [Baltic states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltic_states "Baltic states"), the largest NATO war exercise since the end of the [Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), was held on a reduced scale.[[538]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200320spectator-539)[[539]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200319reuters-540)

The Iranian government was heavily affected by the virus, which infected some two dozen parliament members and political figures.[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-D2Xpc-306)[[540]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-541) Iranian president [Hassan Rouhani](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hassan_Rouhani "Hassan Rouhani") wrote a public letter to world leaders asking for help on 14 March 2020, due to a lack of access to international markets.[[541]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-u2rRX-542) Saudi Arabia, which had launched a [military intervention in Yemen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi_Arabian-led_intervention_in_Yemen "Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen") in March 2015, declared a ceasefire.[[542]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200409foreignpolicy-543)

Diplomatic relations between [Japan and South Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations "Japan–South Korea relations") worsened.[[543]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-544) South Korea criticised Japan's "ambiguous and passive quarantine efforts" after Japan announced travellers from South Korea must quarantine for two weeks.[[544]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-HnqN4-545) South Korean society was initially polarised on president [Moon Jae-in](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon_Jae-in "Moon Jae-in")'s response to the crisis; many Koreans signed petitions calling for Moon's [impeachment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment "Impeachment") or praising his response.[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-imx38-315)

Some countries passed emergency legislation. Some commentators expressed concern that it could allow governments to strengthen their grip on power.[[545]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200331theguardian-546)[[546]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200330nytimes-547) In Hungary, the parliament voted to allow Prime Minister [Viktor Orbán](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viktor_Orb%C3%A1n "Viktor Orbán") to rule by decree indefinitely, suspend parliament and elections, and punish those deemed to have spread false information.[[547]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200330cnn-548) In countries such as [Egypt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"),[[548]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-dw53009293-549)[Turkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey "Turkey"),[[549]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200401foreignpolicy-550) and [Thailand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"),[[550]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-551) opposition activists and government critics were [arrested](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic#Efforts_to_combat_misinformation "Misinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic") for allegedly spreading [fake news](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fake_news "Fake news").[[551]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-20200410straitstimes-552) In [India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_India "COVID-19 pandemic in India"), journalists criticising the government's response were arrested or issued warnings by police and authorities.[[552]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-553)

triples.sentence: The number of journalists imprisoned or detained increased worldwide; some detentions were related to the pandemic.[[536]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-537)[[537]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic#cite_note-538)
triples.statement: The number of journalists imprisoned or detained increased globally, with some detentions being related to the pandemic.
